category_definition: A child whose whereabouts are unknown to their legal guardians or caregivers.
narrative:
Esther (stressed voice): Good day, I'm calling about my daughter, Miry Akinyi. She's only five years old and she went missing this morning in Igembe East Ward, but we don't know which subcounty or exact location. We last saw her playing with Eunice Wairimu, a family friend, near their house. Can you help us find her?
Sarah (comforting voice): I'm so sorry to hear that, Esther. I understand your concern. Can you tell me more about Miry and Eunice? What do they look like, and when did you last see them together?
Esther (anxious voice): Miry is a small girl with curly black hair and brown eyes. She was wearing a red dress and blue shoes when she went missing. We saw her playing with Eunice around 8 AM this morning. Eunice is a tall woman, maybe in her thirties, with long braids and a green shirt. We've been looking for them everywhere but haven't found any trace yet.
Sarah (sympathetic voice): I see, thank you for the details. I will inform the local authorities about the situation and provide them with the descriptions of Miry and Eunice. In the meantime, please keep searching and let us know if there are any new developments.
Esther (relieved voice): Thank you, Sarah. We will do our best to find her. Please keep us updated.

narrative:
John Smith: Good afternoon, you've reached the East African Child Helpline. I'm here to help. Can you tell me about your concern? There seems to be some urgency in your voice.

Caller: Yes, I am very concerned about a girl named Daisy Atieno. She attends school in an unknown location, and I fear she is being mistreated. I haven't been able to confirm the details, but there have been rumors that she is being bullied and possibly neglected by her teachers.

John Smith: I understand your concern. It's important to ensure the safety and well-being of all children. Can you tell me more about these rumors? Who has been spreading them and what specific incidents have been reported?

Caller: Well, I overheard some students talking in a cafe near the school. They said Daisy hasn't shown up to class for several days, and when she does attend, she seems withdrawn and fearful. One student mentioned that she was seen crying outside the school earlier this week.

John Smith: That does sound concerning. I'd like to gather more information before taking further action. Can you describe the location of the school in more detail? This will help us identify the specific institution and potentially locate Daisy.

Caller: Unfortunately, I only know the landmark and ward. The subcounty and county are unknown to me. I wish I could provide more details, but that's all I have.

John Smith: Thank you for what you've shared so far. We'll do our best to locate Daisy and assess her situation. In the meantime, it might be helpful if you could try to find out more information from other reliable sources. If you hear anything that confirms or contradicts these rumors, please let us know immediately.

Caller: I will definitely keep an ear open for any new information. Thank you for your help. This has been weighing heavily on my mind, and it's reassuring to know there's someone looking into this.

John Smith: You're very welcome. We'll do our utmost to ensure Daisy's safety and well-being. If you need to speak with me again or have more information, please don't hesitate to call. Take care.

category_definition: The condition of lacking stable, safe, and adequate housing.
narrative:
Daisy Nyaboke (Medical Professional): Good day, I'm contacting the helpline regarding one of my patients, Vincent Kimeli. He is 14 years old and resides in an unknown location within Kimorori/Wempa Ward, but I believe he may be homeless due to some unfortunate circumstances.
Helpline Agent: I see, thank you for reaching out. Can you please tell me more about the situation?
Daisy Nyaboke (Medical Professional): Unfortunately, his home life is quite challenging. He has an older sister, Angy Akinyi, who has been struggling with substance abuse issues. Lately, she has become increasingly violent and unpredictable, which has made it difficult for Vincent to stay at home.
Helpline Agent: I'm sorry to hear that. Are there any other family members or support systems available to him?
Daisy Nyaboke (Medical Professional): Not really, unfortunately. His parents passed away a few years ago, and his other siblings are either married or live far away. Vincent has been trying to keep things together on his own, but it's becoming increasingly difficult for him.
Helpline Agent: I understand. In such circumstances, it's crucial that we find a safe and supportive environment for Vincent. Would you be open to discussing potential resources or solutions?
Daisy Nyaboke (Medical Professional): Yes, please. I would greatly appreciate any assistance you can provide.

category_definition: Customary behaviors that may have harmful effects on a child’s wellbeing or development.
narrative:
Rose Waboshe (shaking, breathless): Hello, I need someone to help me. My daughter Angy Wakio... she's only thirteen and... I don't know what to do. She's in trouble because of some traditional practice.
Sarah (compassionate, empathetic): I'm so sorry to hear that, Rose. Can you tell me more about what happened?
Rose Waboshe (voice trembling): It's the FGM... Female Genital Mutilation. My husband... he took Angy to perform this... ritual... and now she's in so much pain. She won't eat, she can't sleep... she just cries all day and night.
Sarah (sympathetic): I understand how difficult this must be for you. Let me assure you that you have made the right decision by reaching out for help. Can you tell me where Angy is currently? We need to get her immediate medical attention.
Rose Waboshe (desperate, pleading): She's... she's in Igoji East Ward, Unknown Subcounty, Meru County. But we have to be careful... John Aboge... my husband... he's violent when he's angry. We can't go to the police or anyone will know.
Sarah (soothing, understanding): I understand your concerns, Rose. Let me connect you with our confidential support line for such cases. While we work on getting Angy the help she needs, we also need to ensure your safety and hers.
Rose Waboshe (grateful, relieved): Thank you... thank you so much. You don't know how much this means to me.

category_definition: A birth defect involving incomplete development of the spine and spinal cord.
narrative:
Eunice: Good day, I've been trying to reach someone about my son Jon. He has spinal bifida and it's been... tough. We live in an Unknown Landmark, Port Reitz Ward, Unknown Subcounty, Mombasa County, but things have become unbearable.
Agent: I understand your concern, Eunice. Can you tell me more about the issues you've been experiencing?
Eunice: It started when Petero Mwangi, who has been taking care of Jon, began showing signs of neglect and abuse. He's not providing proper medical attention or even enough food. I've tried speaking to him, but he just... dismisses my concerns.
Agent: That sounds very distressing. I want you to know that you're not alone in this. We can help. Have you contacted any local authorities regarding this matter?
Eunice: Not yet. I'm afraid. I don't know who to trust anymore, and Jon... he's too young to understand what's happening. I just want him to be safe and get the care he needs.
Agent: I completely understand your fear, Eunice. It's important to prioritize Jon's safety. Let me guide you on how to report this case to the local authorities. Once reported, we can also provide further assistance and resources for both of you.
Eunice: Thank you so much... I just needed someone to listen. I'll take your advice and reach out to the authorities as soon as possible.
Agent: That's great to hear, Eunice. We're here to help whenever you need us. If you encounter any challenges or have further questions, don't hesitate to call back. Remember, it's crucial to prioritize Jon's well-being.

narrative:
Angy Wairimu has been forced into an arranged marriage by her family. John Smith, a concerned neighbor, reached out to the East African Child Helpline. The wedding is scheduled for next week in an unknown location within the county. Angy has expressed her unwillingness to marry but her parents have threatened her with disownment if she refuses. She feels trapped and scared, unsure of what to do or where to turn.

John: Hi, I hope you can help me. There's a young girl in our neighborhood named Angy Wairimu. I believe she's being forced into an arranged marriage against her will. Her family has threatened her with disownment if she refuses. The wedding is scheduled next week and I don't know what to do.

Helpline Agent: I see, thank you for reaching out. It's important that we take action to protect Angy. Can you tell me more about the situation? Where does this marriage ceremony take place?

John: I'm not exactly sure of the location. All I know is that it's somewhere within the county. Her family has been very secretive about it, only telling her the day before.

Helpline Agent: Alright, I understand. We need to find a way to locate Angy and provide her with support. Have you spoken to her directly about this?

John: Yes, I have. She's terrified and feels trapped. She doesn't know what to do or where to turn for help.

Helpline Agent: I'm truly sorry to hear that. We can provide Angy with counseling services and information about her rights. It might also be helpful if she can stay somewhere safe until the wedding is postponed or cancelled. Can you help us find a place for her to stay?

John: I don't have the resources to offer her a place, but maybe we can reach out to local organizations for assistance.

Helpline Agent: That's a great idea! Let me provide you with contact information for some local child protection agencies and shelters that can help Angy. In the meantime, it would be best if she could avoid any contact with her family until we can find a safer solution.

John: I will do everything in my power to help Angy. Thank you so much for your assistance.

category: Child in Conflict with the Law
narrative:
Hello, thank you for reaching out to our helpline. I'm here to help. Can you tell me what's on your mind today? There seems to be some concern regarding a child named Miriam who is currently in conflict with the law, as per your report. Could you please share more details about her situation and any related events?

I understand this might be a difficult topic to discuss, but it's important that we get as much information as possible to offer appropriate guidance. Can you tell me where Miriam is currently located? Have there been any incidents of violence or abuse involved in this case? And if so, are there any known suspects or perpetrators?

It's also essential to consider Miriam's safety and well-being. Do you know if she has access to support networks like family, friends, or trusted adults who can help her during this time? If not, we might need to explore other options for ensuring her safety and offering the necessary assistance.

I appreciate your patience as we work through this together. If there's anything else you think I should know, please feel free to share it with me now.

I appreciate your patience as we work through this together. If there's anything else you think I should know, please feel free to share it with me now.

category_definition: The unlawful taking or removal of a child from their legal guardian or safe environment.
narrative:
Violet Monanka (teary voice): Good day, I'm reaching out because I'm so worried about my granddaughter, Miry Nyabuto. She's been living with us for some time now due to her mother passing away. Lately, things have taken a turn for the worse. Miry was supposed to return home from school yesterday, but she never came back. We've tried calling her phone, but it's switched off. I fear something terrible may have happened.
Operator (calm and empathetic): I'm truly sorry to hear about this distressing situation, Violet. Can you tell me more about Miry's step-parent, Miry Wairimu? Have there been any issues between them in the past that could lead to such an action?
Violet (anxious): Well, to be honest, things haven't always been smooth between them. Miry Wairimu has never really liked having Miry around. She often complained about her being a burden and even threatened to send her away once. I've tried my best to keep the peace, but now I fear the worst.
Operator (sympathetic tone): I understand your concern, Violet. It's crucial that we take immediate action to ensure Miry's safety. Can you provide me with more details about where and when she last attended school?
Violet (stressed voice): She attends Sergoit Primary School in the Sergoit Ward of Unknown Subcounty, Uasin Gishu County. She left for school around 7:30 AM yesterday morning but never returned home by evening.
Operator (firm tone): Thank you for that information, Violet. I'll immediately notify the local authorities and ask them to investigate this matter as soon as possible. In the meantime, I'd like to advise you not to discuss this with anyone else, just in case the perpetrator tries to cover their tracks.
Violet (relieved): Thank you so much for your help. I feel a bit better knowing someone is working on finding Miry. I'll stay vigilant and hope for the best.

category_definition: Online Child Sexual Exploitation and Abuse – sexual abuse or exploitation of a child facilitated via the internet.
narrative:
Mary Wawuda (Caller): Hello, I need help. There's a girl named Violet Waboshe, she's only 12 years old and lives in some unspecified location within Nyiro Ward, Samburu County. I fear she might be in trouble. I've seen Vincent Mkamburi, a family friend to her, behaving strangely around her for quite some time now.
Helpline Agent: I see, thank you for reaching out. It's crucial we take this seriously. Can you tell me more about what concerns you?
Mary Wawuda (Caller): Yes, of course. Last week, I saw them both outside their home, and Vincent seemed to be whispering something in Violet's ear. She looked scared, and when she saw me, she ran away. I didn't want to intrude, but it worried me.
Helpline Agent: That does sound concerning. Have there been any other incidents like this?
Mary Wawuda (Caller): Well, there was another time when Violet came to my house visibly shaken. She wouldn't tell me what happened, but she looked very upset. I tried talking to her, but she broke down in tears and ran away again. I don't know if it's related, but it's been troubling me.
Helpline Agent: It's understandable that you're worried, Mary. We need to take action to ensure Violet is safe. Could you provide me with more details about her location?
Mary Wawuda (Caller): I can't give you an exact address as it's rural and not well-known, but she lives in Nyiro Ward, Samburu County, near the riverbed where they often fetch water.
Helpline Agent: Thank you for that information. I will forward this report to our social workers, who specialize in child protection cases like these. They'll work with local authorities to investigate further and provide assistance if necessary.
Mary Wawuda (Caller): That makes me feel a bit better knowing someone is looking into it. Thank you so much for your help. I just hope Violet is alright.

category_definition: Any physical condition that limits a person’s mobility, physical capacity, or stamina.
narrative:
Miriam: Hello, I'm reaching out to you from the East African Child helpline. I am very worried about my neighbor's child, Jacob Mwakio. He's ten years old and lives in a house nearby, but I don't know exactly where it is, in Ndithini Ward, an unknown Subcounty, Machakos County. The reason for my call is that I have reason to believe he might be physically abused by his teacher, Ken Aboge.
Helpline Agent: I understand your concern, Miriam. Let's try and gather more information about this situation. Can you please tell me what made you suspect that Jacob is being abused?
Miriam: Yes, of course. Last week, Jacob came to play with my children, and he was limping badly. He said he had fallen from a tree while playing but his injuries were quite severe for just a simple fall. I asked him about it again the next day, and he looked scared and tried to change the subject. Yesterday, when I went to visit them, I found Jacob's shirt torn and stained with what appeared to be blood. When I confronted Ken Aboge about it, he became very defensive and refused to answer my questions.
Helpline Agent: Thank you for sharing this information, Miriam. I appreciate your vigilance in protecting children. The signs of physical abuse you've described are concerning. I will need to report this to the appropriate authorities immediately.
Miriam: That sounds like a good idea. I just hope someone can help Jacob soon. He seems like such a sweet boy and doesn't deserve to suffer.
Helpline Agent: Agreed, Miriam. Child protection is everyone's responsibility. I will ensure that the necessary steps are taken to investigate this matter thoroughly. In the meantime, please try to keep an eye on Jacob and gather more evidence if you can, but do not put yourself in harm's way. If you need further assistance or have any updates, feel free to call us again.
Miriam: Thank you so much for your help. I will certainly do that. Take care.

category_definition: Any action that causes harm or potential harm to a child, including physical, emotional, or sexual abuse.
narrative:
Hello, thank you for reaching out to the East African Child Helpline. I'm here to help. Can you please tell me what's on your mind today?
Caller: Yes, I have a concern about my granddaughter Miry Wakio. She's only eight years old and lives with her mother in an unknown location within Ziwa Ward, Uasin Gishu County. Recently, I've noticed that she seems distressed and withdrawn. She's been having trouble sleeping and has started wetting the bed again. I asked her about it, but she just says she's fine.
Agent: I'm really sorry to hear that Miry is going through a tough time. It's important to address these concerns promptly. Have you noticed any physical signs of abuse or neglect?
Caller: Not exactly, but her mother has become quite aggressive towards her, yelling and screaming at her for the smallest things. I worry about what she might be doing when I'm not around.
Agent: I understand your concerns. It sounds like Miry may be experiencing emotional abuse. This is a serious issue that can have long-lasting effects on a child's development. Have you considered speaking to Miry's mother about this?
Caller: I've tried, but she becomes defensive and denies anything is wrong. She insists that Miry is just misbehaving.
Agent: It can be difficult to confront someone close to us about their behavior, especially when they deny the problem. However, it's crucial to ensure Miry's safety. I would recommend reaching out to local child protection services for assistance. They can provide guidance on how to approach this situation and offer support for both you and Miry.
Caller: That sounds like a good idea. Do you have the contact information for these services?
Agent: Yes, I can help with that. Here is the contact information for the Uasin Gishu County Child Protection Unit: [Contact Information]. They will be able to provide further assistance and resources. It's also important to remember that it's okay to seek help for yourself as well during this difficult time.
Caller: Thank you so much for your help. I feel a bit more hopeful now. I'll reach out to them right away.
Agent: You're very welcome. I'm glad I could assist. If you need anything else or have any further concerns, please don't hesitate to call back. Take care.

category_definition: Concerns involving laws, child protection, or guardianship requiring legal assistance.
narrative:
Esther Akinyi's cries for help echoed through the phone line. A sense of urgency filled her voice as she spoke in hushed tones. "I... I don't know what to do," she stammered, her words barely audible. "Please, someone needs to help me."
A pause filled the air as she took a deep breath. "It's Mike Sali, Ma'am. He... he touched me in ways that no one should," she whispered, her voice trembling with fear. "He promised not to do it again but... I don't think he will stop."
The counselor listened intently, offering silent support as Esther continued to pour out her fears and worries. "I told my parents, but they said it was just a misunderstanding," she sobbed. "But I know it wasn't. I can feel it in my bones that something terrible is going to happen if I don't do something."
"Esther, I want you to know that what happened is not your fault," the counselor said gently, her voice calm and reassuring. "You are not alone, and there are people who can help you."
The counselor explained the steps Esther could take to ensure her safety. She detailed the process of reporting the incident to the police and the support services available to help her cope with the trauma. "Remember, it's important that you stay safe," she emphasized. "If Mike Sali continues to bother you, don't hesitate to reach out for help."

category_definition: A pattern of behavior that impairs a child's emotional development or sense of self-worth.
narrative:
Vincent: Hi there, I called about a month ago regarding a child named Miry Wakio who's been subjected to emotional abuse in her home. I was told someone would follow up, but I haven't heard anything since. I'm really worried for her, you see? She's just five years old...
Sarah: Hello Vincent, I apologize for any inconvenience. I'm Sarah from the child protection team. I remember your case and I've been looking into it. The situation is quite complex, as we don't have an exact location for Miry's home. We're doing our best to gather more information and locate her family in Witu Ward, Lamu County.
Vincent: That sounds good, but I'm concerned about her safety. Jon Mwangi, her father, has been abusive towards her. He's not provided for her needs and he often yells at her. It breaks my heart to see a child suffering like that...
Sarah: I understand your concern, Vincent. We take such cases seriously. Our first priority is the safety and well-being of children. We've been working with local authorities to try and find Miry and her family. Once we have more information, we'll do everything possible to ensure her safety and provide necessary support.
Vincent: I appreciate that. It's been a long time since I last saw Miry, so I don't know if she's still at the same place. I can't keep quiet about this any longer...
Sarah: Vincent, please trust us to handle this situation. We're doing everything we can and will keep you updated as soon as we have more information. In the meantime, if you see or hear anything about Miry, no matter how small, please don't hesitate to call us again.

category_definition: The act of compelling a person into marriage against their will.
narrative:
Eunice (breathless): Hello? Oh thank goodness someone answered... I need help, please... My niece, Mary Monanka, she's only 11 years old and... It's Jon Mkamburi, he's a family friend and he's forcing her to marry him! She ran away last night and is somewhere in Gatunga Ward, Tharaka-Nithi County but I don't know where exactly. She's scared and so am I... What can we do?
Operator (calm): I'm so sorry to hear about this, Eunice. It sounds like a very difficult situation for both you and Mary. Firstly, let me assure you that you have taken the right step in reaching out for help. Now, let me guide you through some steps we can take to keep Mary safe...
Pause...
Operator (sympathetic): Have you contacted the local police yet? It's important that they are aware of the situation and can begin searching for Mary as soon as possible.
Eunice (panicked): No, I haven't. I didn't know what to do or who to turn to...
Operator (compassionate): That's alright, Eunice. I can help you with that. Let me connect you with our local law enforcement. Hold on a moment please...
Pause...
Operator (firm): Alright, Eunice. I have connected you to the local police. Please provide them with all the details we've discussed and ask for Officer Gikonyo. He is familiar with child protection cases and will assist you effectively. Remember, it's important that Mary is not put in harm's way while searching for her.
Eunice (relieved): Thank you so much. I really appreciate your help. I'm going to call the police now...

category_definition: The illegal restriction of a child's freedom of movement or liberty.
narrative:
Violet Nyabuto (granted): Hello, I need to talk about my granddaughter Mary Atieno. She's thirteen years old and she's been confined by her father James Mwakio in an unknown location within Mukutani Ward, Baringo County. This has been going on for weeks now. I haven't heard from her, and the last time I spoke with her, she sounded scared.
Helpline Agent (empathetic): I'm really sorry to hear that, Violet. Can you tell me more about what's happened? What made you suspect she's in danger?
Violet Nyabuto (concerned): She's never been this quiet before. Her school called me last week saying she hasn't shown up for weeks. I tried calling her, but her phone is off. James has also stopped answering my calls. I fear something terrible has happened to her.
Helpline Agent (sympathetic): It sounds like you're going through a very difficult time. Have you considered reaching out to the local authorities or Mary's school for help? They might be able to assist in locating her.
Violet Nyabuto (determined): I have, but they haven't been much help. They said there isn't enough evidence and that I should wait until she reaches out. I can't just sit here and do nothing while my granddaughter is potentially in danger.
Helpline Agent (supportive): I completely understand your concern, Violet. It's crucial to prioritize Mary's safety. Have you tried contacting any local NGOs that focus on child protection? They may have resources to help you.
Violet Nyabuto (frustrated): Yes, I did. But most of them said they can't intervene without a formal report or legal documentation. I don't have any of that because James hasn't allowed us to see Mary for so long.
Helpline Agent (empathetic): It's unfortunate that you're facing these challenges, but there might still be options available. Have you considered speaking with a lawyer about getting a court order to locate and protect Mary?
Violet Nyabuto (hopeful): That's something I hadn't thought of before. I don't have much money, but maybe there's a pro bono legal aid service that can help me.

category_definition: A pregnancy occurring in a female under the age of 20.
narrative:
Rose Akinyi: (tearfully) Hi, I need to talk. My daughter, Miry Wakesho, she's only four years old and... she's pregnant. I don't know what to do or who to turn to.
Sarah: (compassionately) I'm so sorry to hear that. Can you tell me more about the situation? How did this happen?
Rose Akinyi: (voice shaking) It happened at the school where she goes. The coach, Peter Mutie, he... he took advantage of her. I didn't know until recently when she started showing signs. She's so scared and doesn't want to talk about it.
Sarah: (gently) I see. This is a very difficult situation. I want you to know that there are resources available to help you. First, it's important for Miry to receive immediate medical attention and care. We can help find a local healthcare facility where she can be examined and treated.
Rose Akinyi: (anxiously) What about the coach? What will happen to him?
Sarah: (firmly) The police should be involved in cases like this, especially when a child is harmed. We can assist you in reporting the incident and connecting with the appropriate authorities.
Rose Akinyi: (sobbing) I don't know if I can do this. I don't want her to have to go through this alone.
Sarah: (empathetically) You are doing the best thing for your daughter by seeking help. It's important that she understands she's not to blame and that there are people who care about her. We can also connect you with counselors who specialize in child trauma and abuse. They can provide support for both of you during this difficult time.
Rose Akinyi: (whispering) Thank you. I don't know what I would do without your help.
Sarah: (calmly) You're not alone. We're here to support you and Miry every step of the way. I will provide you with the necessary information and resources to ensure your daughter receives the care she needs. Please remember that it's essential to prioritize her safety and well-being during this time.
Rose Akinyi: (gratefully) Thank you, Sarah. I appreciate everything you're doing for us.

narrative:
Eunice has been struggling with substance abuse for quite some time now. John Smith, a concerned neighbor from her same locality reached out to our helpline. Eunice is believed to be engaging in excessive alcohol consumption and potentially abusing drugs as well. Her behavior has taken a turn for the worse recently, with frequent absences from home, uncharacteristic aggression, and a notable decline in personal hygiene.

John: Good day, I hope this line is connected to the right place. I'm calling regarding Eunice Chao. She lives nearby and I've noticed some changes in her behavior that concern me.

Helpline Agent: Hello, John, and thank you for reaching out. How can I assist you today?

John: Well, it's about Eunice. She's been acting strangely lately. Her house is usually neat and tidy, but now there are bottles strewn around and she smells of alcohol every time I see her. The other day, she got into a fight with her landlord over some unpaid rent, and it ended up quite violent.

Helpline Agent: I'm sorry to hear about Eunice's situation. It sounds like there might be a substance abuse issue involved. Have you noticed any signs of drug use as well?

John: To be honest, I haven't seen anything that looks like drugs, but her behavior has become erratic and unpredictable. She's been missing work for days at a time and when she does show up, she's barely coherent. It's really worrying me.

Helpline Agent: Substance abuse can lead to a variety of problems, including job loss, physical harm, and mental health issues. It's important that we take action to help Eunice. Have you tried talking to her about your concerns?

John: I have, but she becomes defensive and denies there's a problem. She claims it's none of my business and tells me to mind my own affairs. I don't know what else to do.

Helpline Agent: It can be difficult to convince someone with an addiction to seek help, especially if they're in denial. However, there are resources available that can provide assistance. We can explore some options and possibly come up with a plan to address this issue.

John: That would be greatly appreciated. I just want Eunice to get the help she needs before things escalate even further.

category_definition: Intentional aggressive behavior that involves an imbalance of power or strength, typically repeated over time.
narrative:
Miry has been experiencing bullying at school from her step-father, Petero Mwakio. The incidents began when Miry's mother remarried, and Petero started making derogatory comments about her previous husband and insinuating that she brought shame to the family. This escalated to physical abuse, with Petero slapping and kicking Miry whenever he was intoxicated.
Daisy Wairimu, a community member, reported the issue to the East African Child helpline after witnessing Petero's behavior towards Miry. She expressed her concern about the girl's well-being, as the abuse has been ongoing for several months. Miry is afraid to tell anyone due to fear of further retaliation from Petero.
Upon receiving the report, the helpline agent assured Daisy that they would take immediate action to ensure Miry's safety. The agent emphasized the importance of reporting such incidents and commended Daisy for her bravery in speaking up. The agent further informed Daisy about available resources for victims of gender-based violence and provided a list of local organizations that could offer support.
The agent then explained that Miry would be offered counseling services to help her cope with the trauma and regain her confidence. They also assured Daisy that they would work closely with law enforcement to apprehend Petero and ensure he faces justice for his actions. The agent emphasized that everyone has the right to live free from violence and abuse, and urged Daisy to continue supporting Miry during this difficult time.

category_definition: The legal process by which a person becomes the legal parent of a child not biologically theirs.
narrative:
Ken Sali: (trembling voice) Hello there, I hope you can help me. My daughter Violet Wakesho, she's only thirteen, and we don't know where she is. She ran away from home a few days ago, and no one has heard from her since.
Helpline Agent: I'm really sorry to hear that, Mr. Sali. Can you tell me more about what happened? When did Violet leave, and why do you think she might have run away?
Ken Sali: (sobbing) She left after an argument with Daniel Muema, her peer from school. They had a fight, and he threatened to hurt her if she told anyone. Violet was afraid and ran away. We've searched everywhere but can't find her.
Helpline Agent: I see. That sounds very concerning. Have you reported this incident to the local authorities?
Ken Sali: (shaking) Yes, we did, but they said there wasn't enough evidence to pursue the case. They suggested we contact a child protection agency for help.
Helpline Agent: I understand your frustration, Mr. Sali. In cases like these, it's crucial to act quickly. Let me connect you with our child protection counselor who can guide you through this process and offer some advice on what steps to take next.
Ken Sali: (relieved) Thank you so much. I appreciate your help.

category_definition: Control or restriction of access to financial resources, often as a form of abuse.
narrative:
Rose Waboshe (Social Worker): Good day, Daniel. I've been informed about your situation and I'd like to offer my support. Tell me, what's been going on?
Daniel Muema (Victim): Ma'am... it's complicated. My father, Peter Mutie, he's been taking all our money. He says it's for the business but we don't have food or anything. We sleep hungry most nights. I don't understand why he does this to us.
Rose: I'm truly sorry to hear about your hardship, Daniel. It's not right for anyone, especially a child, to go hungry. Have you spoken to someone about this before?
Daniel: (tearfully) Yes, I did. But they said there was nothing they could do because he controls everything. They even took me away from school because of the fees. I just feel so lost and alone.
Rose: You are not alone, Daniel. I'm here for you now. What you're going through is called financial abuse, and it's illegal. It's important that we find a solution to help you and your family.
Daniel: (whispering) How can we do that? I don't know anyone who can help us.
Rose: There are organizations that can help. They can provide legal aid, counseling, and even temporary housing if needed. But first, I need to know where you are so I can send someone to assist you immediately. Can you tell me your location?
Daniel: (hesitant) I'm in Kariobangi South Ward, Unknown Subcounty, Nairobi City County. But please be careful if you come here. My father is violent and he may harm us if he finds out.
Rose: Your safety is of the utmost importance. We'll make sure to proceed cautiously. In the meantime, I want you to remember that what's happening to you is not your fault. You have a right to live in a safe and nurturing environment.
Daniel: (sobbing) Thank you, ma'am. I don't know what I would do without you.
text:
Rose Waboshe (Social Worker): Good day, Daniel. I've been informed about your situation and I'd like to offer my support. Tell me, what's been going on?
Daniel Muema (Victim): Ma'am... it's complicated. My father, Peter Mutie, he's been taking all our money. He says it's for the business but we don't have food or anything. We sleep hungry most nights. I don't understand why he does this to us.
Rose: I'm truly sorry to hear about your hardship, Daniel. It's not right for anyone, especially a child, to go hungry. Have you spoken to someone about this before?
Daniel: (tearfully) Yes, I did. But they said there was nothing they could do because he controls everything. They even took me away from school because of the fees. I just feel so lost and alone.
Rose: You are not alone, Daniel. I'm here for you now. What you're going through is called financial abuse, and it's illegal. It's important that we find a solution to help you and your family.
Daniel: (whispering) How can we do that? I don't know anyone who can help us.
Rose: There are organizations that can help. They can provide legal aid, counseling, and even temporary housing if needed. But first, I need to know where you are so I can send someone to assist you immediately. Can you tell me your location?
Daniel: (hesitant) I'm in Kariobangi South Ward, Unknown Subcounty, Nairobi City County. But please be careful if you come here. My father is violent and he may harm us if he finds out.
Rose: Your safety is of the utmost importance. We'll make sure to proceed cautiously. In the meantime, I want you to remember that what's happening to you is not your fault. You have a right to live in a safe and nurturing environment.
Daniel: (sobbing) Thank you, ma'am. I don't know what I would do without you.

category_definition: Any physical condition that limits a person’s mobility, physical capacity, or stamina.
narrative:
Vincent Aboge: (sighs heavily) Hello, I've been trying to find someone to help me. My daughter, Esther Waboshe, she's only eight years old and... I don't know what to do.
Agent: (compassionate tone) I'm sorry for the trouble you're going through, sir. Can you tell me what happened?
Vincent Aboge: (voice trembling) She... she was playing outside when my wife's step-parent, Esther Chao, found her. She scolded her harshly and then... then she picked up a wooden rod and started hitting her with it. My little girl... she fell to the ground and didn't move. I was terrified.
Agent: (alarmed) That sounds serious, sir. Is Esther okay now? Has she received medical attention?
Vincent Aboge: (distressed) She's alive, but she's unable to walk or talk properly. The doctor said she has a fractured spine and her speech might be affected. I... I don't know what to do, who to turn to.
Agent: (sympathetic tone) I understand your concern, sir. It's important that Esther receives the necessary care for her injuries. Have you reported this incident to the authorities or any child protection services?
Vincent Aboge: (voice breaking) No, not yet. I... I didn't know where to start. My wife doesn't want me to involve the police or anyone else. She says it would bring shame upon our family. But I can't just let this go.
Agent: (firm tone) Sir, it's crucial that you take action to ensure your daughter's safety and wellbeing. I can help you report this incident anonymously if you wish. Additionally, I can provide you with information about local child protection services and legal options available to you.
Vincent Aboge: (relieved) Yes, please. Anything you can do would be appreciated. I just want my daughter to be safe and get the help she needs.

category_definition: Problems such as performance, discipline, bullying, or lack of resources at school.
narrative:
Miry Gachoka: Hi there, I'm calling regarding Eunice Atieno. She's been having some issues at her new job and it's affecting her schoolwork. She works for Peter Mwakio in Kabianga Ward, but I don't know the exact location.
Helpline Agent: I see. That sounds concerning. How long has she been working there?
Miry Gachoka: For about a month now. At first, things were okay, but recently Peter's been demanding more from her and it's becoming too much. He even threatened her the other day.
Helpline Agent: That's very serious. Have you reported this to any authorities?
Miry Gachoka: No, I haven't. Eunice is afraid that if she does, Peter might retaliate. She needs a job to support herself and her younger siblings.
Helpline Agent: I understand your concern. It's crucial for Eunice's safety and well-being to take action. Let's first ensure she's safe. Can you bring her to a safe location until we can find a solution?
Miry Gachoka: (Pauses) Yes, I can do that. But what about Peter? What will happen to him?
Helpline Agent: We will handle the situation with appropriate authorities and ensure he faces consequences for his actions. It's important to prioritize Eunice's safety at this moment. Once we have a safe plan in place, we can discuss further steps.
Miry Gachoka: Okay, I understand. Thank you for your help.
Helpline Agent: You're welcome. I'll arrange for someone to contact you soon regarding the next steps. In the meantime, please keep Eunice safe and try to gather any evidence that may support her case.

category_definition: The presence of two or more disabling conditions in an individual.
narrative:
Hello, you're speaking with Sarah at our Crisis Support Services. How may I assist you today?
Caller: Hi, I'm Daisy Wairimu. I have a friend named Angy Gachoka who lives in an unknown location within Nginda Ward of Unknown Subcounty in Embu County. She's been through a lot recently and I am deeply concerned about her well-being.
Sarah: I'm really sorry to hear that, Daisy. Can you tell me more about what's happening with Angy?
Caller: Yes, she's been struggling with multiple disabilities since birth. Her father, Daniel Mkamburi, has been physically and emotionally abusive towards her due to these challenges. He believes she is a burden and he doesn't provide the necessary care or support for her needs.
Sarah: I understand this must be difficult for both of you. Is there anyone else in Angy's life who can help or support her?
Caller: She has an aunt, Mary Wambui, but she lives far away and hasn't been able to provide much assistance. The nearest school for children with disabilities is miles away from their home, so it's a struggle for Angy to attend regularly.
Sarah: I appreciate your concern for Angy. Our crisis support services can offer information on resources that may be available in her area to help with her care and education needs. We also provide counseling services if you'd like to talk more about how best to support Angy during this difficult time.
Caller: Thank you, Sarah. That would be greatly appreciated. Can you send me information on the schools and resources for children with disabilities in her area? I'll do my best to help her access these services.
Sarah: Of course, Daisy. I can provide you with the contact details of local organizations and schools that offer support for children with disabilities. Additionally, we have counselors available to speak with both you and Angy if needed.
Caller: That sounds like a plan. Thank you so much for your help. I'll reach out to the contacts you provide and take it from there.
Sarah: You're very welcome, Daisy. Please remember that our services are always available if you need someone to talk to or further information. Take care.

category_definition: Emotional or romantic relationships between adolescent individuals.
narrative:
Jon Sali: Hi, I'm calling about my granddaughter, Daisy Nyabuto. She is only five years old and lives in an unknown landmark in Mayenje Ward, but I don't know which subcounty. My daughter left her with her step-father, Ken Kimeli, after a recent argument, and now I am very worried.
Agent: I see, Mr. Sali. I'm so sorry to hear about your concerns. Can you tell me more about what happened? Has there been any physical harm done to Daisy?
Jon Sali: No, not yet as far as I know, but I fear for her safety. Ken has always shown a lack of patience with children and often loses his temper. I worry that he might hurt her.
Agent: It's crucial we get help for Daisy immediately. Can you provide more details about where she is currently? Have you contacted local authorities or any child welfare services?
Jon Sali: No, I haven't. I don't know who to turn to. The situation has been escalating, and I feel helpless.
Agent: I understand your concerns, Mr. Sali. It is essential to prioritize Daisy's safety. Here are some steps you can take: First, call the police at 999 or visit your local police station to file a report about your fears for Daisy's welfare. Second, contact Childline Kenya, which operates a 24-hour helpline at 116, specifically for cases like this one.
Jon Sali: Thank you so much. I'll do that right away. Can you also tell me about any other resources or organizations that can help?
Agent: Of course! The National Council for Children Services (NCCS) is a government agency dedicated to child welfare, and they may be able to offer additional support. You can visit their website at www.nccs.go.ke or call them on +254 20 271 4849.
Jon Sali: Thank you for all your help. I really appreciate it. I'll contact the police and Childline Kenya right away.
Agent: You're welcome, Mr. Sali. Please remember that if there is any immediate danger or harm to Daisy, do not hesitate to call the police or seek emergency assistance immediately. Your granddaughter's safety is paramount, and we want her to be in a safe environment as soon as possible.
Jon Sali: Thank you again. I'll keep you updated on our progress.

category_definition: An individual's overall sense of personal worth or value.
narrative:
Miry Wawuda: Hello, I've been trying to find help for my daughter Esther Atieno. She's fifteen now and lives in Chemosot Ward, but I don't know the exact subcounty. She's been going through a lot lately, and I fear she might be struggling with her self-esteem.
Agent: I see, I'm sorry to hear that. Can you tell me more about what's been happening?
Miry Wawuda: It started a few months ago. Esther used to be such a vibrant girl, full of life. But ever since her father, Jon Kibet, started his verbal abuse, she's been different. He always puts her down and compares her to other girls in the neighborhood. I've tried talking to him, but he doesn't seem to understand or care.
Agent: That sounds incredibly difficult for Esther. It's important to address this situation before it escalates further. Have there been any physical signs of distress?
Miry Wawuda: Yes, she's been losing weight and hasn't been eating properly. She stays in her room most of the time, barely talks to anyone, and when she does, it's clear she's upset. I don't know what to do to help her.
Agent: It sounds like Esther needs professional help. I can provide you with some resources for counseling services that might be able to assist her. Would that be helpful?
Miry Wawuda: Yes, please. Anything to help my daughter. She's so lost right now.
Agent: Alright, I'll send you some information on local counseling centers that specialize in adolescent mental health issues. They can provide Esther with the support she needs to navigate through this difficult time.
Miry Wawuda: Thank you so much. I really appreciate your help.
Agent: You're welcome, Miry. Remember, it's okay to ask for help when you need it. Take care of yourself as well during this time. Good luck to Esther.

category: Child in Conflict with the Law
category_definition: A minor who has allegedly committed or been accused of committing an offense under the law.
narrative:
Hello, you've reached the Child and Gender Protection Helpline. How can I assist you today?
Peter (distressed): Hi, I need to report something about my daughter, Violet. She's only seven years old and... she's in trouble.
Helpline Agent: I'm really sorry to hear that. Can you tell me what happened?
Peter: Well, she's been skipping school lately. And when I asked her why, she said some boys from her class have been bullying her. They took her new shoes and... and they made her do things she shouldn't.
Helpline Agent: I see. That sounds very serious. Have you spoken to the school about this issue?
Peter: Yes, I did. But they said there was no evidence and Violet is the one who keeps missing school. They even suspended her for a week. I don't know what to do.
Helpline Agent: It's important to take these matters seriously. Let's see if we can help you find a solution. Firstly, I would suggest documenting any evidence of the bullying or abuse. If there are any witnesses, it would be beneficial to speak with them as well.
Peter: What do you mean by documentation? Should I write everything down?
Helpline Agent: Yes, that's a great start. You could also take pictures of any visible injuries or damaged property if there are any. If Violet is willing, recording her conversations with the perpetrators could provide more evidence. But be aware that this should only be done if it can be done safely and legally.
Peter: I see... That's a lot to take in. What should I do next?
Helpline Agent: Next, you should contact local child protection services. They have the resources and expertise to investigate this matter further and provide support for Violet. If you don't know who to contact, I can help you find the right resources in your area.
Peter: That would be really helpful. Thank you so much for listening. I feel a bit more hopeful now.

category_definition: Any sexual act or attempt to obtain a sexual act through coercion or without consent.
narrative:
Esther Monanka: Hi, I'm calling about my daughter Violet Nyabuto. She's been through a terrible ordeal and we need help. It happened at an unknown landmark in Yimbo East Ward, in an unknown subcounty of Siaya County. A man named Jon Mutie... he... he did something to her. I don't know what to do.
Agent: I'm so sorry to hear that. I can only imagine how difficult this must be for you and your family. Let me help you find some resources, okay? Firstly, we need to ensure Violet is safe and receiving the necessary medical attention. Can you tell me where she is right now?
Esther Monanka: She's with a neighbor, but I fear she won't be safe there for long. I don't know how to approach this...
Agent: It's important that we get her to a safe place as soon as possible. Can you contact the local police and inform them about what happened? They should be able to provide assistance and ensure Violet's safety. While you do that, I can help you connect with some organizations that specialize in providing support for survivors of sexual violence.
Esther Monanka: (pausing) Okay... okay. I will contact the police. What about these organizations? Can they help us find Jon Mutie too?
Agent: They can certainly assist in reporting the incident and gathering evidence, which may help in identifying and apprehending the perpetrator. It's crucial that we document everything thoroughly to increase the chances of justice being served. In addition, these organizations can provide counseling services for Violet and your family. The trauma she has experienced will require ongoing support to heal from.
Esther Monanka: That sounds like a good plan. Thank you so much for your help. I'm feeling a little overwhelmed right now, but I know we'll get through this.
Agent: You're doing an amazing job by reaching out for help. I want to remind you that it's okay to ask for support during this difficult time. I have some contacts for organizations in your area that can offer assistance and guidance. I will send them to you via text message as soon as possible. In the meantime, if there's anything else I can do or any questions you have, please don't hesitate to call back.
Esther Monanka: Thank you again. I really appreciate your help.

category_definition: A formal or informal union involving a child below the age of 18.
narrative:
Angy Gachoka (Medical Professional): Good day. I'm reaching out to you concerning a patient under my care, Esther Akinyi. She is 14 years old and recently confided in me that she has been forced into a marriage within Lolgorian Ward, an unknown subcounty in Narok County.
Helpline Agent: I see. I'm sorry to hear about this. Can you tell me more details about the situation?
Angy Gachoka (Medical Professional): Yes, of course. Esther revealed that Violet Nyaboke, a family friend, has been arranging her marriage to an older man. She disclosed feeling trapped and scared, as she fears for her future and safety.
Helpline Agent: That's very concerning. I can offer some help and resources. Firstly, it's important that Esther remains safe. Have you considered reaching out to local authorities or social services?
Angy Gachoka (Medical Professional): Yes, but I wanted to get in touch with someone who specializes in child protection matters first. I'm unsure of how to proceed and felt it would be best to seek guidance before taking action.
Helpline Agent: You've made the right decision by reaching out. I can help you navigate this situation. Let me gather some information, and then I'll provide a plan of action.
[Pause]
Helpline Agent: I have researched some resources that might be helpful for Esther's case. Firstly, the Child Protection Unit in Narok County can offer assistance in handling child marriage cases. I recommend contacting them and informing them about Esther's situation. Additionally, there are organizations providing legal aid and counseling services for victims of child marriages that we could reach out to.
Angy Gachoka (Medical Professional): Thank you so much for your help. This has been a heavy burden on my shoulders, and I appreciate your guidance.

category_definition: Any physical condition that limits a person’s mobility, physical capacity, or stamina.
narrative:
Miry Gachoka (anonymous to Angy Wawuda): I've been informed about a concerning situation involving a young girl named Angy Wawuda. She is five years old and resides in an unknown location within Mukutani Ward, Baringo County. The incident reported suggests that she has suffered physical harm.
Helpline Agent (Sarah): I understand the gravity of the situation. Can you tell me more about what happened to Angy? Has there been any medical attention provided?
Miry Gachoka: Yes, it's terrible. The perpetrator is Daniel Sali, a teacher at her school. He has physically abused Angy. She was admitted to a nearby hospital but has since been discharged without proper care or follow-up. I fear for her safety and wellbeing if nothing is done.
Helpline Agent: I'm deeply concerned about Angy's situation as well. Let's try to ensure she gets the help she needs. Can you provide me with the hospital where she was admitted? It's important we contact them and follow up on her case.
Miry Gachoka: Unfortunately, I don't have that information. But Angy lives in a village near a stream called 'Eburu'. The school is close to there. If someone goes to the school, they might be able to find out more about where she was taken for treatment.
Helpline Agent: Thank you for providing that information. I'll send an emergency response team to investigate Angy's situation and provide any necessary medical assistance. In the meantime, can you reach out to local authorities in Baringo County and inform them about the incident? It will help expedite the process.
Miry Gachoka: Absolutely. I'll do my best to contact the authorities as soon as possible. Thank you for your quick response and assistance. Please keep me updated on Angy's condition.

category_definition: Failure to provide necessary care, supervision, or support to a child.
narrative:
Violet Akinyi: (trembling voice) Hello? I... I need to talk. It's about Esther, my granddaughter. She's in danger, and no one is listening.
Helpline Agent: (calm and empathetic tone) I'm here to listen, Violet. Can you tell me what's happening?
Violet Akinyi: (voice cracking) It's her father, James Mwakio. He's neglecting her. She's just 15, and he treats her like she's nothing. I try to help, but he... he won't let me.
Helpline Agent: I'm sorry to hear that, Violet. Have there been any specific incidents you can share?
Violet Akinyi: (distressed) Yes, last week... she came home with bruises on her arms. She said James had lost his temper and hit her. I tried to talk to him, but he just laughed it off.
Helpline Agent: That's not acceptable behavior, Violet. Have you reported this to the authorities?
Violet Akinyi: (hesitant) No... I was afraid of what James might do if I did. He's violent, and I don't want Esther to suffer more because of me.
Helpline Agent: Your concern for Esther is commendable, Violet. It's crucial that she receives the help she needs. I can assist you in reporting this to the appropriate authorities.
Violet Akinyi: (relieved) Thank you. Please, do something. She deserves better than this.
Helpline Agent: I will ensure Esther's case is handled promptly and appropriately. In the meantime, it's important for Esther to be in a safe environment. Can she stay with you?
Violet Akinyi: (determined) Yes, of course. As long as it takes to put an end to this.
Helpline Agent: That's a great decision, Violet. I will keep you updated on the progress of the case and provide any additional support you may need. Take care.

category_definition: A diet that contains the proper proportions of carbohydrates, fats, proteins, vitamins, and minerals.
narrative:
Esther, my dear, please take a deep breath. I understand that you're going through a tough time. I'm here to listen and offer some support. Tell me, what seems to be troubling you? Jon Kimeli called, concerned about your wellbeing. He mentioned that you've been skipping meals due to lack of food at home.
This is a serious matter, Esther. Skipping meals can lead to poor health and impaired cognitive development, especially during these crucial growing years. I understand it might be difficult, but try to eat something nutritious whenever possible. Fruits, vegetables, lean proteins, and whole grains are essential for a balanced diet.
I know things might seem overwhelming right now, but remember, there's always help available. Jon Kimeli mentioned that he's reaching out to local organizations for assistance. In the meantime, I can provide you with some resources that may be helpful. There are several food banks and community kitchens in Weiwei Ward that offer free meals to those in need.
I'm really glad you reached out today, Esther. It takes a lot of courage to ask for help. Remember, it's okay not to be okay sometimes. If things get too much to handle, don't hesitate to reach out again. I'm here for you, and so are many others who care about your wellbeing.

category_definition: Involving a child in sexual activity that they cannot comprehend or consent to.
narrative:
Daisy Atieno: (whispering) Hello? Can you hear me? I need to speak with someone... about my daughter.
Counselor: (calm and reassuring) Yes, hello. I'm here to help. Please tell me what happened.
Daisy Atieno: (voice shaking) It's Daisy Gachoka, she's only four years old... she was with Petero Mkamburi, a family friend... and something terrible has happened.
Counselor: I see. Can you tell me more about what transpired? When and where did this occur?
Daisy Atieno: (voice breaking) It was yesterday in Unknown Landmark, Mkunumbi Ward, Subcounty... Petero took her to play near the river and then... I don't know what happened but when she came back she was crying and scared.
Counselor: That sounds very concerning. Has anyone sought medical attention for Daisy?
Daisy Atieno: (frantic) No, not yet. I was waiting for her to calm down but she keeps reliving the trauma... She's shaking and won't stop crying.
Counselor: It's important that Daisy receives immediate medical attention, as well as psychological support. I'll help you get connected with resources in your area. In the meantime, can you keep her calm and safe until help arrives?
Daisy Atieno: (tearful) Yes, of course... but what if something happens again? What can we do to prevent this from happening?
Counselor: I understand your concern. It's crucial to report the incident to the authorities and to keep Daisy away from Petero Mkamburi. We can also provide you with information on how to protect your child from sexual abuse and resources for ongoing support.
Daisy Atieno: (sighing) Thank you... I don't know what I would do without your help.
Counselor: You're welcome, Daisy. I'm here for you and your daughter. Please hang on while I connect you with our referral specialist who can provide you with more information and resources.

category_definition: The fundamental rights entitled to every child, including protection, education, and healthcare.
narrative:
Miry Akinyi, a three-year-old girl, has been in our care for a week now following reports of abuse by her family friend, Mary Akinyi. The incident occurred at an unknown landmark in Kikuyu Ward, Unknown Subcounty, Kiambu County. Today's call is to provide an update on Miry's situation and to discuss the next steps.
Ken Mwangi, Miry's parent, has been cooperative throughout this process, sharing details about Mary's frequent visits and erratic behavior towards his daughter. He expressed concerns about Miry's emotional well-being and her inability to sleep peacefully at night. He also mentioned that Miry has been having nightmares, reliving the traumatic event.
During our initial conversation, I assured Mr. Mwangi that we would do everything in our power to ensure Miry's safety and provide her with the necessary support. We immediately started the legal process to apprehend Mary Akinyi and secure a safe place for Miry.
Since then, Miry has been staying at a temporary shelter, where she is receiving counseling and medical care. The team of professionals working with her is doing an excellent job helping her cope with the trauma. They have noticed signs of improvement, such as increased appetite, fewer nightmares, and improved interactions with other children.
However, we are aware that this is just the beginning of a long journey towards healing for Miry. We plan to transfer her to a long-term care facility once a suitable one becomes available. In the meantime, Mr. Mwangi has been allowed to visit his daughter at the shelter and has been actively involved in her recovery process.
Mr. Mwangi expressed gratitude for our assistance but also asked about Mary Akinyi's whereabouts. I informed him that she is currently in police custody and will remain there until the legal proceedings are complete. I emphasized the importance of the ongoing investigation to ensure justice for Miry and prevent such incidents from happening again.
As we ended the call, Mr. Mwangi seemed relieved but still concerned about his daughter's future. I assured him that our team will continue to support Miry throughout her recovery and provided him with contact information for regular updates.

category_definition: Infliction of physical injury upon a child through actions like hitting or shaking.
narrative:
Miry Chao: Good day, I'm calling regarding my grandson, Peter Kimeli. He's fourteen years old and lives in North Gem Ward, an unknown subcounty in Siaya County. Unfortunately, his sister Angy Akinyi has been physically abusing him. I've noticed bruises on his body and he seems withdrawn. Yesterday, he was not at school, and when I asked him about it, he cried and said Angy had beaten him again. This isn't the first time this has happened. I fear for his safety.
Agent: I'm so sorry to hear about your grandson, Miry. Child abuse is a grave concern, and we're here to help. It's crucial that Peter receives immediate medical attention for those visible injuries. Can you please help me find a nearby health facility where he can be examined? If possible, please keep him there until social welfare services can intervene.
Miry Chao: Yes, I understand. I'll take him to the clinic immediately. But what about his sister? We need her to stop this abuse once and for all.
Agent: That is a very important concern, Miry. Our team can assist with that as well. We will reach out to local law enforcement and child protection services to investigate this matter further. If found guilty, Angy will be held accountable for her actions. In the meantime, we recommend you keep Peter in a safe environment away from his sister.
Miry Chao: Thank you so much for your help. I'm still scared about what might happen if she finds out that I contacted you.
Agent: It's completely normal to feel concerned about safety during such situations, Miry. Rest assured that our team will ensure confidentiality throughout this process. We will work diligently to protect both Peter and your family. If you have any more concerns or need further assistance, please don't hesitate to call us again.

narrative:
John Smith: Hello, I've reached out to the helpline again. It's been a few weeks since we last spoke about Eunice Chao. I hope she's doing better now?

Helpline Agent: Hi John, thank you for your concern and for checking up on her. Unfortunately, I don't have any updates regarding Eunice as of yet. We are still trying to locate her exact whereabouts and reach out to offer our services.

John Smith: (deep sigh) It's just... I feel helpless. She's such a sweet girl and she doesn't deserve what life has thrown at her. I've noticed she's been withdrawing more, not eating properly, and seems to have lost all interest in things she used to love.

Helpline Agent: I understand your concern, John. Self-esteem issues can be quite challenging, especially when coupled with other stressors such as unknown circumstances or living conditions. Eunice might be struggling with feelings of worthlessness or hopelessness. It's crucial that we reach her soon to provide the support she needs.

John Smith: Yes, exactly. And it breaks my heart knowing she's going through this alone. What can I do to help? Is there anything I can tell her to encourage her to seek help when we find her?

Helpline Agent: Absolutely, John. You can remind her that she is strong and capable of overcoming any obstacles that come her way. Encourage her to focus on the things she loves and try to reconnect with them whenever possible. Let her know that there are people who care about her and want to help. And most importantly, reassure her that it's okay to ask for help when things get tough.

category_definition: Cases that do not fall neatly into predefined categories.
narrative:
Esther Monanka (caller): Hello, I need urgent help. My daughter, Rose Nyabuto, she's only twelve years old and she's been living with Jon Mwangi in Baawa Ward, Samburu County. But lately, things have become unbearable at home. I fear for her safety.
Crisis Support Agent: I'm so sorry to hear that, Esther. Can you tell me more about what has been happening?
Esther Monanka (caller): Yes, it started a few months ago. Jon would get angry over small things and scold Rose harshly. But recently, he began hitting her too. He doesn't seem to care that she's just a child. Last week, he even left a bruise on her arm. I've tried talking to him about it but he just laughs it off.
Crisis Support Agent: I see. This is indeed concerning and could potentially be considered as domestic violence towards a child. It's important that we try to ensure Rose's safety. Are there any family members or trusted individuals she can stay with temporarily?
Esther Monanka (caller): Well, my sister lives in the same subcounty but she has many mouths to feed already. I don't want to burden her more. But I can't let Rose continue living with Jon. She's terrified and so am I.
Crisis Support Agent: It sounds like you're in a difficult situation, Esther. Let me share some options with you. One, we could reach out to the local child welfare services and report this case. Two, if there's no immediate alternative for Rose to stay elsewhere, we could help you prepare a safety plan to minimize her exposure to harm at home. Lastly, we can provide counseling services for both Rose and you to help cope with this stressful situation.
Esther Monanka (caller): Thank you for your help. I'll consider all options. But please, do something quickly. I don't want my daughter to suffer any longer.

category_definition: A pregnancy occurring in a female under the age of 20.
narrative:
Esther (distressed): Hello, I don't know who to turn to. My neighbor, Violet Wakesho, is only three years old and she's pregnant. I've noticed her belly getting bigger and I've asked around, and it seems Kelvin Muema, the child's guardian, might be responsible. I don't know what to do, Sarah.
Sarah (calm, empathetic): I'm so sorry to hear about this, Esther. It's a difficult situation, but we can try to help. Can you tell me more about what you've observed? When did you first notice Violet's belly getting bigger?
Esther (shaken): It's been a couple of months now. I tried talking to Kelvin about it, but he just laughed it off and changed the subject. I don't know what to do, Sarah. I can't stand by while a child is being harmed like this.
Sarah (sympathetic): I understand your concerns, Esther. It's important that we take action to ensure Violet's safety. Have you considered reporting this to the authorities?
Esther (nervous): I haven't, I was afraid. I don't know who to trust or what will happen to Violet if I do. But I can't keep quiet anymore.
Sarah (supportive): That's a difficult decision, but it's the right one. We can help guide you through the process. Can you tell me where Violet lives?
Esther (hesitant): Unknown Landmark, Matuu Ward, Unknown Subcounty, Machakos County.
Sarah (professional): Thank you for providing that information. I'll make sure it gets to the appropriate authorities. In the meantime, it's important that Violet is kept safe and away from Kelvin as much as possible. If you have any more information or concerns, please don't hesitate to reach out to us.

category_definition: Matters requiring legal advice or involving legal rights, disputes, or protection.
narrative:
Eunice Atieno (distressed): Hello, I'm calling about my son, Mike Wanyama. He's thirteen years old and he's staying with his guardian, Mike Mutua, in Chepareria Ward, an unknown subcounty in West Pokot County. I'm concerned because I haven't heard from him for over a week now, and when I reached out to Mr. Mutua, he said Mike is staying with relatives in another village. But I don't trust him, Sarah. Something feels off.
Crisis Support Agent (sympathetic): I understand your concern, Eunice. It's important that you feel heard and supported during this difficult time. Can you tell me a bit more about Mike and his situation?
Eunice Atieno (anxious): He's a good boy, Sarah. Always obedient, always respectful. But ever since he moved in with Mr. Mutua, things have changed. He's become quieter, less talkative. And there was an incident... a few months ago, where I found bruises on his body and Mike said it happened at Mr. Mutua's house. I took him to the hospital, and they said he was okay. But ever since that day, he hasn't been the same.
Crisis Support Agent (empathetic): That sounds very concerning, Eunice. I'm sorry for what you're going through. If your son is a minor, as I understand, there are laws in place to protect him from harm and neglect. Have you reported this incident to the local authorities or any child protection agency?
Eunice Atieno (determined): No, I haven't. I was scared, Sarah. Scared of what Mr. Mutua might do if I did. But now... now I'm worried sick about my son. I can't let this go on any longer.

Eunice Atieno (distressed): Hello, I'm calling about my son, Mike Wanyama. He's thirteen years old and he's staying with his guardian, Mike Mutua, in Chepareria Ward, an unknown subcounty in West Pokot County. I'm concerned because I haven't heard from him for over a week now, and when I reached out to Mr. Mutua, he said Mike is staying with relatives in another village. But I don't trust him, Sarah. Something feels off.
Crisis Support Agent (sympathetic): I understand your concern, Eunice. It's important that you feel heard and supported during this difficult time. Can you tell me a bit more about Mike and his situation?
Eunice Atieno (anxious): He's a good boy, Sarah. Always obedient, always respectful. But ever since he moved in with Mr. Mutua, things have changed. He's become quieter, less talkative. And there was an incident... a few months ago, where I found bruises on his body and Mike said it happened at Mr. Mutua's house. I took him to the hospital, and they said he was okay. But ever since that day, he hasn't been the same.
Crisis Support Agent (empathetic): That sounds very concerning, Eunice. I'm sorry for what you're going through. If your son is a minor, as I understand, there are laws in place to protect him from harm and neglect. Have you reported this incident to the local authorities or any child protection agency?
Eunice Atieno (determined): No, I haven't. I was scared, Sarah. Scared of what Mr. Mutua might do if I did. But now... now I'm worried sick about my son. I can't let this go on any longer.

category_definition: Practices surrounding safe and nutritious food preparation and feeding habits.
narrative:
Jon Mwakio (Caller): Hi there, I need urgent help. My son Vincent Aboge, he's only three years old and I don't know what to do. He hasn't eaten anything since yesterday morning. We have no food at home and I can't find any to buy either. I'm worried sick about him.
Crisis Support Services Agent: I'm so sorry to hear that, Jon. It sounds like a difficult situation you're in. Can you tell me more about why there's no food at home?
Jon Mwakio (Caller): Well, we were doing okay until my employer laid me off last month. We used our savings to survive for a while but now they're gone and I can't find another job. My wife is sick too, she needs medication that we can't afford.
Crisis Support Services Agent: That must be very hard for you and your family. Let's see what we can do to help Vincent get some food. Have you reached out to any local organizations or charities that might be able to assist?
Jon Mwakio (Caller): I tried, but no one seems to be able to help us. They said there's not enough to go around and they can only help those in more dire need. I don't know what to do.
Crisis Support Services Agent: I understand how desperate you must feel right now, Jon. But please remember that you're not alone. There are resources available that might be able to help your family get through this tough time. Let me see if I can find some organizations in your area that could potentially assist.
(Long pause)
Crisis Support Services Agent: I found a few local charities and food banks that provide assistance to families in need. They may not be able to solve all of your problems, but they could help ease the burden for now. Can I connect you with one of them?
Jon Mwakio (Caller): Yes, please. Anything would be better than nothing at this point.
Crisis Support Services Agent: Alright, I'll transfer you to a representative from the Riwo Ward Food Bank. They should be able to provide you with some immediate assistance and possibly longer-term support as well. Hang on just a moment while I connect you.
(Sound of phone transferring)
Riwo Ward Food Bank Representative: Hello, this is the Riwo Ward Food Bank. How may I assist you today?

category_definition: The condition of lacking stable, safe, and adequate housing.
narrative:
Angy Atieno: Hi there, I'm Angy, a teacher at Violet Akinyi's school. I hope you can help me. There's something concerning about our young student. We haven't seen her for days now and no one seems to know where she is. She usually lives with her guardian Ken Muema, but he hasn't been around either.
Helpline Agent: I see, that does sound troubling. Can you tell me more about Violet? How old is she and what does she usually look like?
Angy Atieno: Violet is six years old. She's quite small for her age, with a round face and dark curly hair. We last saw her wearing a red sweater and blue jeans. She's been living with Ken Muema in Ndoto Ward, Samburu County, but the exact location is unknown.
Helpline Agent: Alright, I understand. It's important we find Violet as soon as possible. Do you have any idea where Ken might be?
Angy Atieno: To be honest, no one does. He hasn't been at home for a while now and he doesn't answer his phone either. We've tried contacting him but to no avail. I fear something bad might have happened to Violet.
Helpline Agent: I understand your concern, Angy. I can report this case to the appropriate authorities and they will begin an investigation. In the meantime, I would recommend you to spread the word among the community about Violet's disappearance. The more eyes looking for her, the better chances we have of finding her.
Angy Atieno: Thank you so much. That sounds like a good plan. I will start reaching out to people right away. Please, keep me updated on any progress.

category_definition: Practices surrounding safe and nutritious food preparation and feeding habits.
narrative:
Daisy Gachoka: Hello, I've been trying to reach someone about James Mkamburi. I'm concerned about his well-being. He lives in Kiogoro Ward, but I don't know the exact subcounty.
Helpline Agent: Thank you for reaching out. I understand your concern. Can you tell me more about what's troubling James?
Daisy Gachoka: Well, it started a few days ago when he mentioned that there wasn't enough food at home. His stepfather, Jacob Aboge, has been away working and hasn't sent any money for groceries. I tried to help by sending some food, but it seems it's not enough.
Helpline Agent: I see. It's important that James receives regular meals. Hunger can affect his health and school performance. Have you reached out to Jacob Aboge regarding this matter?
Daisy Gachoka: Yes, I did. But he said he doesn't have the money right now. He promised to send some soon, but I worry that James might not be able to wait that long.
Helpline Agent: It's understandable to be concerned. In situations like these, it's crucial to ensure James gets the support he needs. Do you know if there are any local organizations or resources that could provide food assistance?
Daisy Gachoka: I don't have much information on that, but I believe there should be some. I was thinking of reaching out to the local authorities, but I wasn't sure who to contact or what process to follow.
Helpline Agent: I can help with that. Let me find some resources for you. In the meantime, is there anyone else who could temporarily support James with food while we sort this out?
Daisy Gachoka: I'll see if I can find someone. But it might take some time. In the meantime, anything would be helpful.
Helpline Agent: Alright. I've found some organizations in Kisii County that provide food assistance to vulnerable children. I'll send you their contact information along with some guidance on how to approach the local authorities.
Daisy Gachoka: Thank you so much! This means a lot to me and James. I really appreciate your help.
