category_definition: A diet that contains the proper proportions of carbohydrates, fats, proteins, vitamins, and minerals.
narrative:
Miriam Wakesho: Hi there, I have a concern about my friend Miriam Anyango. She's been having a difficult time lately and I think she might need some help. Lately, her health has been deteriorating and I suspect it could be due to lack of proper nutrition. She lives in North Monyerero Ward, in an unknown Subcounty, Kisii County, but the exact location is not clear.
Helpline Agent: I see, thank you for reaching out. It's important that we help Miriam as soon as possible. Can you tell me more about her situation? How long has she been experiencing these symptoms and what kind of food is she eating?
Miriam Wakesho: It's been about two months now. She used to eat a balanced diet, but lately, it seems like she's only having one meal a day which is mainly ugali and beans. I know she hasn't had any vegetables or fruits in weeks. I also noticed that she's lost a significant amount of weight.
Helpline Agent: That does sound concerning. Lack of proper nutrition can lead to serious health issues if not addressed promptly. I would recommend that we provide Miriam with information on the importance of a balanced diet and the benefits it has for her overall health.
Miriam Wakesho: Yes, I agree. But how do we reach her? She's been very secretive about her struggles recently.
Helpline Agent: We can try reaching out to her through text messages or phone calls. If that doesn't work, we could also involve a local community leader who might be able to help us locate her and get the message across. In the meantime, it would be helpful if you could keep an eye on her and let us know if there are any changes in her condition.
Miriam Wakesho: I will do my best. Thank you so much for your help.
Helpline Agent: You're welcome, Miriam. We'll work together to ensure that Miriam gets the help she needs. Take care and feel free to reach out if you have any questions or concerns. Goodbye for now.

category_definition: The partial or total removal of external female genitalia for non-medical reasons.
narrative:
Eunice: Hi, I've been worried about my friend Jacob Mwakio. He's only three years old and lives with Ken Sali in an unknown location within Voo/Kyamatu Ward, Kitui County. I think something terrible might have happened to him. Eunice takes a deep breath before continuing, her voice trembling.
I saw Jacob the other day and... he looked different. He was crying uncontrollably and wouldn't stop screaming. When I asked what was wrong, Ken just said that he had fallen while playing outside. But I know Jacob well, and he didn't seem to be hurt in a way that would cause so much pain.
A few days later, I visited again and I noticed something unusual. Jacob seemed to be walking differently, like he was in great discomfort. His mother passed away recently, and Ken is his guardian now. I asked him about it, but he just got angry and pushed me away.
Today, I saw Jacob again, and... well, I'm scared. He didn't want to play or eat. He kept rubbing himself with a small cloth and making these strange noises. It broke my heart, and I couldn't take it anymore. I need help.

category_definition: Problems such as performance, discipline, bullying, or lack of resources at school.
narrative:
Rose Atieno: (distressed) Hello, I need help, please. My grandson Ken Aboge is just three years old and he's in trouble. He's been going to a local school in Bunyala West Ward, but recently, his older brother Jacob Kibet has been hurting him.
Pause...
Rose Atieno: (voice shaking) Every day when I drop Ken off at the school, I see Jacob push him, pull his clothes and even hit him. I've tried talking to Jacob but he just laughs it off, saying that he is only playing with his little brother. But I know better.
Pause...
Rose Atieno: (concerned) Yesterday, Ken came home with a big cut on his cheek. When I asked him about it, he said Jacob had scratched him with a stone. I've reported this to the school authorities, but they say they can't do anything unless there is concrete evidence.
Pause...
Rose Atieno: (frustrated) I don't know what to do. I fear for Ken's safety every day he goes to that school. He's just a baby, and he doesn't understand why his own brother would hurt him like this. I need someone to help me protect him.

Pause...
Rose Atieno: (voice shaking) Every day when I drop Ken off at the school, I see Jacob push him, pull his clothes and even hit him. I've tried talking to Jacob but he just laughs it off, saying that he is only playing with his little brother. But I know better.
Pause...
Rose Atieno: (concerned) Yesterday, Ken came home with a big cut on his cheek. When I asked him about it, he said Jacob had scratched him with a stone. I've reported this to the school authorities, but they say they can't do anything unless there is concrete evidence.
Pause...
Rose Atieno: (frustrated) I don't know what to do. I fear for Ken's safety every day he goes to that school. He's just a baby, and he doesn't understand why his own brother would hurt him like this. I need someone to help me protect him.

category_definition: Emotional or romantic relationships between adolescent individuals.
narrative:
Esther Akinyi is in a crisis. She's been in an abusive relationship with a boy named Daniel Mwakio, but he's now vanished without a trace, leaving her alone and afraid. Jacob Mkamburi, her guardian, found her shaking and sobbing. He knows something is wrong and reaches out to the helpline for help.
Jacob: (Anxious tone) Hello, I need someone to speak with urgently. My granddaughter Esther... she's not herself. She's been crying all day, and I can't seem to comfort her. She won't tell me what's wrong.
Agent: (Compassionate tone) I understand how distressing this must be for you. Let's see if we can help Esther feel a bit better. Have you asked her directly about what's troubling her?
Jacob: (Frustrated tone) Yes, I have. But she keeps brushing me off and saying it's nothing. I just don't believe her.
Agent: It can be difficult for young people to open up, especially when they're going through something traumatic. Let's try another approach. Can you ask Esther if there's anyone who might have upset her recently? A friend, a family member, or perhaps a classmate?
Jacob: (Sigh) I'll try that. But she's been very secretive about this whole thing. I worry it's something worse than just a disagreement with a friend.
Agent: It's important to take her concerns seriously, as they could be related to her safety and well-being. If you need help figuring out how to approach the topic with Esther, I can provide some guidance. In the meantime, it might be helpful for you to share that she can reach out to us if she ever needs someone to talk to.
Jacob: (Grateful tone) Thank you, that's a good idea. I appreciate your help. I'll speak with her soon and let you know how things go.
Agent: You're very welcome, Jacob. I hope everything works out for Esther. If she does reach out to us, please remind her that we're here to listen without judgment, and our services are confidential.

category_definition: A situation where a child lacks a responsible adult to provide basic care and support.
narrative:
Rose Akinyi (caller): Hello, I need to talk about something that's been bothering me for a while now. There's this girl, Mary Waboshe, she's only 14 years old and lives in Olkeri Ward, but I don't know the exact subcounty. She's been left alone by her caregiver, Jacob Muema, and it's been weeks now.
Helpline Agent: I see, thank you for reaching out about this matter. It's crucial we do something to help Mary. Can you tell me more about the situation?
Rose Akinyi (caller): Yes, of course. Jacob left her with no food or money and hasn't been back since. Mary's been wandering around, looking for him but he's nowhere to be found. I tried talking to him, but he just ignored me. I don't know what to do.
Helpline Agent: I understand your concern, Rose. This is a serious matter that requires immediate attention. Let's work together to find a solution for Mary. First, we need to report this incident to the authorities and ensure her safety. We can also try reaching out to local organizations that provide support for children in need.
Rose Akinyi (caller): That sounds like a good plan. I'll contact the police right away. As for the local organizations, do you have any suggestions?
Helpline Agent: Yes, here are some organizations that might be able to help. They specialize in child protection and welfare.
1. Kajiado County Children's Department - Contact number: 07XXXXXXX254
2. The African Network for the Prevention and Protection Against Child Abuse and Neglect (ANPPCAN) Kajiado Chapter - Contact number: 07XXXXXXX654
3. NGO CARE Kenya - Contact number: 07XXXXXXX894
Rose Akinyi (caller): Thank you so much for your help. I'll reach out to them immediately and also contact the police as you suggested.
Helpline Agent: You're welcome, Rose. I'm glad I could assist you. Remember, if you need more help or have any updates regarding Mary's situation, don't hesitate to call back. We're here for you.

category_definition: The condition of lacking stable, safe, and adequate housing.
narrative:
Esther: Hi there, I'm calling about a little girl named Rose Monanka. She lives with her guardian, John Kibet, in an unknown location within Muruka Ward, Subcounty, Murang'A County. The issue is that Rose has been homeless for quite some time now and it's getting worse.
Agent: I see, I'm really sorry to hear about Rose. Could you tell me more about her current situation? Where is she staying at the moment?
Esther: Well, she hasn't had a permanent place to sleep for months. John claims he can't afford rent and keeps moving them from one temporary shelter to another. The latest place they stayed was not suitable for a child and Rose fell sick due to poor conditions.
Agent: That sounds very concerning. What kind of place was it? And how is her health now?
Esther: It was an old, run-down building with holes in the walls and no proper facilities. Rose caught a fever from the cold and lack of proper bedding. She's better now, but she's weak and scared of going back to such conditions.
Agent: I understand your concerns. It's important that Rose receives proper care and a safe living environment. Are there any local organizations or authorities you could reach out to for help?
Esther: I have contacted the local child welfare office, but they said their resources are limited and they can't provide immediate assistance. I don't know what else to do.
Agent: Don't worry, we might be able to offer some guidance. Let me connect you with our housing and homelessness unit. They can provide information about available services and potentially help find a safer place for Rose. Is that okay?
Esther: Yes, please. I would really appreciate any assistance. Thank you for listening to me.

category_definition: Concerns related to sexual development, reproductive systems, consent, and health education.
narrative:
Miry had been living with her guardian, Mike Muema, in North Karachuonyo Ward, but recently she felt a growing sense of unease. Angy Nyaboke, a community member, noticed Miry's change in behavior and approached her.
"Miry, what's wrong?" asked Angy with concern.
"I... I don't know," Miry replied, trying to hold back tears. "Mike's been acting strange lately."
Angy placed a comforting hand on Miry's shoulder. "Tell me more about it."
Miry hesitated before speaking again. "He touches me in places he shouldn't... and he wants me to do things I don't want to do." She looked down, ashamed.
Angy gasped in horror. "That's not right! You shouldn't have to deal with that. Have you told anyone else?"
"No," Miry whispered. "I didn't know who to tell or what would happen if I did."
"You need to tell someone," Angy insisted. "I'll help you. Let's go find a safe place and report this to the authorities."
Miry looked up, hope flickering in her eyes. "What if he finds out?"
Angy patted Miry's hand reassuringly. "We'll make sure he doesn't. We have to protect you, Miry."

Angy patted Miry's hand reassuringly. "We'll make sure he doesn't. We have to protect you, Miry."

category_definition: A condition affecting cognitive functioning, behavior, or emotional control.
narrative:
Esther Wairimu: Good day, Crisis Support Services. I'm calling regarding a student named Violet Waboshe, who is currently in Grade One at our school in Mwanganthia Ward, but I'm afraid I don't have the exact subcounty or postal code.
Helpline Agent: Of course, thank you for reaching out. Could you please tell me more about Violet and the concerns you have?
Esther Wairimu: Well, she has been acting differently lately. She seems anxious all the time, barely eats anything at lunch, and doesn't want to play with other children. Yesterday, she even wet her uniform during class. I believe something is troubling her deeply.
Helpline Agent: I see. It sounds like Violet might be going through a difficult time. Have there been any significant changes in her life that could be causing this?
Esther Wairimu: Not that she's shared with us, but one of the parents mentioned Kelvin Wanyama, who lives nearby. I don't know much about him, and Violet doesn't seem comfortable talking about him either.
Helpline Agent: It is important to take these concerns seriously. Given Violet's age, it might be beneficial for her to speak with a professional counselor who can help her process her feelings in a safe and supportive environment. I would recommend reaching out to the local child protection services or a trusted mental health organization.
Esther Wairimu: Thank you so much for your advice. I'll look into that right away. It means a lot to have someone listen and provide guidance during this difficult time.

narrative:
John Smith calling, I need your help. A young boy named Peter Mwangi is being forced into marriage against his will. He's very scared and confused. I found out about this when he came to me for advice. He told me that Alex Anonymous, someone who lives in an unknown location, has been pushing him to marry an older woman. The wedding is supposed to take place next week, but Peter is determined not to go through with it. He's running away and needs a safe place to stay. I don't know where he is right now, or how to help him.

I tried talking to Alex, but he became aggressive, saying that this is tradition and that Peter has no say in the matter. I'm scared for Peter's safety if he runs away. I don't know what to do. Can you help?

(Long pause)

I can see how distressed you are, John. This is a very serious situation and we need to act quickly to keep Peter safe. Let me gather some information from you first. Where exactly does Alex live, if you know? And where has Peter been staying lately?

(Another long pause)

Okay, I have the basic details. Now let me explain what we can do. First, I'll reach out to local authorities and inform them about the situation. We'll ask for their help in locating Peter and ensuring his safety. Second, we'll provide him with counseling services to help him cope with this traumatic experience. And third, we'll work on finding a safe place for him to stay until this issue is resolved.

I understand that you may not be able to remain involved in this process due to your own safety concerns, but please know that we will do everything in our power to help Peter. We'll keep you updated as much as possible.

category_definition: Same as above, including academic, behavioral, or structural challenges in schools.
narrative:
Hello, you've reached ChildLine Kenya. How can I assist you today? I'm here to listen.
Caller (neutral tone): Hi, I need some advice. My son, Kelvin Sali, is just five years old and he's been having trouble at school in Bura Ward, Taita Taveta County. The teacher said he's not learning as fast as the other children, and his step-father... John Mwangi... has been verbally abusing him about it.
Helpline Agent (empathetic tone): I'm really sorry to hear that, sir. It's important to remember that every child learns at their own pace. This situation seems quite serious. Let's see if we can find some help for Kelvin and your family.
Caller (anxious tone): Yes, it has been getting worse lately. He's so afraid of going to school now. The other day he came home with a bloody nose... I think John Mwangi may have hit him.
Helpline Agent (firm tone): That is a serious concern, sir. Violence towards a child is never acceptable under any circumstances. We should report this immediately. Let me provide you with the contact details for the local Child Protection Unit in Taita Taveta County. They can assist with the necessary steps to protect Kelvin.
Caller (hesitant tone): I... I don't want John Mwangi to get into trouble, but... I just want Kelvin to be safe and happy at school.
Helpline Agent (supportive tone): I understand your concerns, sir. The most important thing is the safety and well-being of your son. Reporting this incident will ensure that proper action can be taken to ensure Kelvin's protection and help him overcome these challenges. Would you like me to connect you with someone from the Child Protection Unit?
Caller (relieved tone): Yes, please do. I... I really don't know what else to do. Thank you for your help.

category_definition: Cultural, traditional, or religious acts that cause physical or psychological harm, such as FGM.
narrative:
Jacob Mwakio: (deep breath) Hello, I... I need to speak with someone. My son, Jon Kibet, he's in trouble. He's only thirteen, and I don't know what to do.
Helpline Agent: I'm sorry to hear that you're going through this. Can you tell me what happened?
Jacob Mwakio: (distraught) It's... it's in Mata Ward, Unknown Subcounty, Taita Taveta County. James Mwangi, Jon's father, he's been... he's been hurting Jon. I don't know how to stop him.
Helpline Agent: I understand this must be very difficult for you. It's important that we get Jon the help he needs. Can you tell me more about what James has been doing?
Jacob Mwakio: (hesitant) He... he beats Jon, sometimes with fists, other times with objects. Jon's been hiding it from me, but I've seen the bruises. I just don't know how to make it stop.
Helpline Agent: I'm so sorry for what you and your son are going through. It's crucial that we report this to the authorities. Can I have your contact details so I can provide more information on next steps?
Jacob Mwakio: (nodding, virtually) Yes, of course. My number is... (gives number)
Helpline Agent: Thank you for trusting us with this. We'll do everything we can to help. In the meantime, please try to keep Jon safe and avoid any confrontations if possible. I'll contact you soon with more information on what to expect next.
Jacob Mwakio: (sigh of relief) Thank you. I don't know what we'd do without your help.

category_definition: A genetic condition resulting in little or no production of the pigment melanin, often leading to stigma or discrimination.
narrative:
Hello, thank you for reaching out to East African Child Helpline. I'm here to assist you. Could you please provide more details about the case regarding Eunice Wakesho?
Caller: Yes, hello. I am John Mkamburi, a teacher at Eunice's school. There seems to be an issue with one of my students, Eunice Wakesho. I have noticed that she has been absent for quite some time now and when she does come, she appears distressed.
Helpline Agent: I see. Could you tell me more about her absence? Has there been any specific incident that might be causing this distress?
Caller: Well, it started around two weeks ago when we found a letter on her desk stating that she is being targeted due to her albinism. The letter was anonymous but it was clear that the neighbor, Eunice Wawuda, has something to do with it. She's always shown disregard towards Eunice and now it seems to have escalated.
Helpline Agent: I understand your concern. This is a serious matter. We need to ensure Eunice's safety immediately. Have you reported this incident to the authorities?
Caller: Not yet, but I was planning to do so today. However, I wanted to get some advice beforehand as this is a sensitive issue and I don't want to jeopardize Eunice's well-being further.
Helpline Agent: That's a wise decision. It's important to approach such matters with caution. I can help you with that. Firstly, please ensure you keep a copy of the letter as evidence. Secondly, I would suggest you report this incident to the local police station and also the child protection unit in your area. They are equipped to handle cases like these.
Caller: Thank you for your advice. I will do that immediately. But what about Eunice? Shouldn't we take her somewhere safe until this is resolved?
Helpline Agent: You raise a valid point. It would be best if she could stay with a trusted relative or friend until the investigation is completed. However, it's crucial that you discuss this with the child protection unit as they can provide more guidance based on the specific circumstances.
Caller: Thank you for your help. I feel a bit more prepared now. I will follow your advice and report to the authorities.

category_definition: The condition of lacking stable, safe, and adequate housing.
narrative:
Mary Akinyi: Hello there, I'm calling for Crisis Support Services. I've a grave concern about one of my students, Vincent Mkamburi, who is seven years old and living in an unknown location within Riabai Ward, Subcounty, Kiambu County. He's been without shelter for quite some time now, and I fear for his safety and well-being.
Agent: I see, thank you for reaching out. It's important to address such situations promptly. Could you please provide more details about Vincent's current whereabouts? This will help us assess the situation better.
Mary Akinyi: Unfortunately, I don't have exact details on his location, but he has been living with Petero Sali, who is his step-parent, for a while now. However, I haven't seen or heard from him in weeks, and that worries me greatly.
Agent: I understand your concerns, Madam Akinyi. The absence of information regarding Vincent's location can make the situation more challenging, but we will do our best to help. We need to locate him first before providing any further assistance. May I have his last known contact details?
Mary Akinyi: Sadly, I don't have any current contact information for either of them. However, Petero Sali can be reached through the school, as he is listed as an emergency contact.
Agent: Thank you for that. We will reach out to the school and gather more information. In the meantime, could you please check if there are any other contacts or people who might know Vincent's whereabouts?
Mary Akinyi: I will certainly try my best to find someone who can help. This situation has been weighing heavily on me, and I am grateful for your assistance. Please let me know once you have more information about Vincent's location.
Agent: Of course, Madam Akinyi. We will keep you updated as soon as we have any developments regarding Vincent's whereabouts. In the meantime, please take care of yourself as well.

category_definition: Issues arising from interactions within the family such as conflict, separation, or neglect.
narrative:
Mike's voice trembled as he spoke, "I don't know what to do... I can't take this anymore." There was a long pause before he continued, his breath hitching. "My uncle... Peter Mwangi... He's been hurting me for a while now. I thought it would stop but it's only getting worse."
A soft voice responded, "I'm so sorry to hear that, Mike. It's not your fault and there's help available. Can you tell me more about what's been happening?"
Mike sighed, his voice shaking even more, "It started a few months ago... he would touch me inappropriately whenever he was drunk. But now... it's worse. He threatens to hurt my family if I say anything."
The listener asked gently, "Has anyone else known about this? A teacher, a friend, or another family member?"
Mike hesitated, then whispered, "No... not yet. I've been too scared to tell anyone. I don't want them to get hurt because of me."
"I understand your fears, Mike," the listener said sympathetically. "But it's important that you find someone who can help you. This is not your fault and there are people who can protect you. Have you considered talking to a trusted adult?"
There was another long pause before Mike managed to speak, his voice barely above a whisper, "I don't know... I don't want to betray my family."
"It's understandable that you feel this way, but remember, it's not about betrayal. It's about getting help and staying safe," the listener emphasized. "Would you like some information about organizations that can help you? Or perhaps a safe way to report this?"
Mike took a deep breath, his voice cracking as he spoke, "Yes... please. I need help."

category_definition: Customary behaviors that may have harmful effects on a child’s wellbeing or development.
narrative:
Violet Wakio: Hello, I'm calling from Kivou Ward, a place far away from where we used to live. I need your help, Sarah. My little sister Violet Gachoka is in trouble. She's just nine years old and she's being subjected to something terrible... something traditional.
Sarah: I'm so sorry to hear that, Violet. Can you tell me more about what's happening?
Violet Wakio: It started a few weeks ago when our guardian, Vincent Sali, brought home a group of elders. They said it was time for an initiation ceremony. I didn't understand what they meant at first, but now... I fear the worst.
Sarah: Initiation ceremonies can be complex and vary greatly from one community to another. Could you describe what exactly is happening to your sister?
Violet Wakio: Every night, she comes home with physical signs of pain. Her body is covered in bruises and she walks as if she's in agony. And when I try to talk to her, she just cries and asks for it all to end.
Sarah: This sounds extremely distressing. Violet, do you know the specific practices that are being performed on your sister?
Violet Wakio: I've heard whispers of circumcision, but I don't want to believe it. It's barbaric and illegal, isn't it?
Sarah: Yes, female genital mutilation is indeed illegal in Kenya. It constitutes gender-based violence and carries severe penalties for those who perform it.
Violet Wakio: (pauses) What can I do to stop this, Sarah? Please tell me there's something I can do.
Sarah: There are organizations that can help you. They provide counseling and support for victims of such practices. I'll connect you with one now.
Violet Wakio: (grateful) Thank you so much, Sarah. Please hurry, my sister needs help.

category_definition: A condition resulting from a diet lacking in essential nutrients.
narrative:
Eunice: Hi, I need to talk about my daughter Violet. She's twelve years old and lives with her caregiver, Jacob Mutua, in an unknown location within Wiga Ward, Migori County. Lately, I've noticed she's become weak and thin, and she seems to have lost interest in food. Her school performance has also dropped significantly.
Agent: I'm sorry to hear that, Eunice. It sounds like Violet might be experiencing malnutrition. Have you taken her to a doctor yet?
Eunice: Yes, we went last week but the clinic was too far and expensive. We couldn't afford the treatment they suggested. Jacob says he can't help because he doesn't earn much either.
Agent: I understand your situation might be challenging, but Violet's health is crucial. Can you consider seeking assistance from other sources or reaching out to local organizations that offer support for children in need?
Eunice: That sounds like a good idea, but I don't know where to start. I've heard about some organizations but I'm not sure if they help cases like mine.
Agent: I can help you with that. Here are the contact details of some local organizations that provide assistance for children and families in need. Also, I'll connect you with a social worker who can guide you through this process and offer additional resources.
Eunice: Thank you so much! I really appreciate your help. I'm scared for Violet and I don't know what to do.
Agent: You're doing the right thing by reaching out for assistance. Don't worry, we'll do everything possible to ensure Violet gets the care she needs. Take care, Eunice, and feel free to call us again if you have any questions or concerns.

category_definition: A genetic condition resulting in little or no production of the pigment melanin, often leading to stigma or discrimination.
narrative:
Angy Wairimu (social worker): Good afternoon, this is Angy Wairimu from Homa Bay County's Child Protection Unit. I have a case that I would like to report, and I believe your services could be beneficial. A four-year-old girl named Violet Waboshe, who lives in an unspecified location within Kagan Ward, has been facing severe difficulties due to her albinism condition.
Helpline Agent: I see, thank you for reaching out and bringing this matter to our attention. Can you please share more details about the situation?
Angy Wairimu (social worker): Yes, of course. Violet's parents, Ken and Mary Mutua, have been neglecting her due to cultural beliefs associated with albinism. They have failed to provide proper care and protection for her, including sunscreen and protective clothing, exposing her to the harmful effects of sunlight that intensify her condition.
Helpline Agent: That sounds alarming. What about Violet's schooling? Has she been attending school regularly?
Angy Wairimu (social worker): No, she hasn't attended school consistently because of her albinism-related stigma and the family's financial struggles. The lack of education has only added to the girl's isolation and vulnerability.
Helpline Agent: I understand your concerns. Are there any signs of physical or emotional abuse that you have observed?
Angy Wairimu (social worker): Yes, there are some concerning signs. Violet shows symptoms of emotional distress, such as frequent crying, night terrors, and withdrawal from social interactions. Additionally, she has developed skin lesions due to prolonged sun exposure.
Helpline Agent: These are grave concerns indeed. I'll do my best to provide assistance in this matter. Could you please tell me the exact location where Violet resides? This will help us initiate an investigation and provide her with the necessary support.
Angy Wairimu (social worker): Unfortunately, the family has moved several times due to the stigma they face, and we are not certain of their current address. But I can share that they were last residing in Kagan Ward, Unknown Subcounty, Homa Bay County.

narrative:
John Smith: Hello there, I hope you're okay. I'm calling from East African Child Helpline. I understand you have a concern about someone?

Long pause...

Mary Atieno: (whispering) Yes... yes, I need help. I've nowhere to go... no place to sleep tonight. I... I don't know what to do.

John Smith: I see, Mary. It sounds like you're going through a difficult time right now. Let me tell you that you're not alone, and we're here to help. Can you tell me more about your situation?

Mary Atieno: (sigh) I... I lost my job last month. My parents live in the village, and I have no family here in the city. I was renting a room, but the landlord kicked me out today because I couldn't pay the rent.

John Smith: I'm sorry to hear that, Mary. Losing a job can be incredibly tough, especially when we don't have support from our families. How long have you been in this city, and are there any friends or acquaintances who might help?

Mary Atieno: (shaking) I came here four years ago to find work. There's no one I can turn to. Everyone I knew has moved on, or they don't have the means to help me.

John Smith: It's understandable that you feel this way, Mary. We have resources available to help you get through this crisis. Firstly, let's focus on finding you a safe place to stay tonight. Can you tell me if there are any shelters or charities in the area that provide temporary accommodation?

Mary Atieno: (hesitant) I... I don't know of any places like that. I didn't think it would come to this.

John Smith: That's alright, Mary. We can find resources for you. In the meantime, let me give you a list of emergency numbers and hotlines in case you need immediate help or support. Remember, you are not alone, and there are people who care about your well-being.

(John Smith provides various contact information and resources)

Mary Atieno: (whispering) Thank you... thank you so much. I don't know what I'd do without you right now.

category_definition: Emotional or romantic relationships between adolescent individuals.
narrative:
Rose: Hi there, I hope I haven't disturbed you. It's about my son, Jacob. He's been going through something and I don't know what to do.
Helpline Agent: Of course, thank you for reaching out. Can you tell me more about what's been happening with Jacob?
Rose: Well, he's always been a quiet boy but lately, he's been acting strange. He doesn't want to talk much and when I try to ask him questions, he gets upset. The other day, I overheard him on the phone with this man named Peter Muema. They were arguing loudly, and I could tell Jacob was crying.
Helpline Agent: That sounds concerning, Rose. Have you spoken to your son about it?
Rose: Yes, I did. He refused to tell me what they argued about. He just said it was none of my business. But I know something's wrong. He's been avoiding his friends and he doesn't want to go to school.
Helpline Agent: It seems like there might be a relationship issue, Rose. Have you considered speaking with a counselor who can help him navigate through this?
Rose: I had thought about it, but I don't know where to start. There aren't many resources in our area and I'm afraid of how he might react if I force the issue.
Helpline Agent: It's understandable that you want to be sensitive to your son's feelings, Rose. However, it's important to remember that his well-being should be a priority. Perhaps we can find a counselor who can offer online sessions or who is based in a nearby location.
Rose: That would be great. I just want him to feel better and get back to being the happy boy he used to be.
Helpline Agent: I completely understand, Rose. I'll do my best to find some resources for you. In the meantime, please encourage Jacob to open up if he feels ready. It might help him to know that there are people who care and want to help.
Rose: Thank you so much. I really appreciate your help.
Helpline Agent: You're welcome, Rose. Take care of yourself too. Remember, it's okay to ask for help when you need it. If you have any other concerns or if Jacob needs immediate assistance, please don't hesitate to call us back. Goodbye for now.

category_definition: Practices surrounding safe and nutritious food preparation and feeding habits.
narrative:
Violet Wakesho: Good day, I'm calling from Rose's school. I hope you're doing well. I have a serious concern about one of our students, Rose Monanka. She is only five years old and has been coming to school hungry for the past week. Yesterday, she fainted during recess. The school nurse said it was due to hunger.
Helpline Agent: Oh dear, that's concerning. I'm so sorry to hear about Rose. Has anyone talked to her family about this?
Violet Wakesho: We've tried reaching out to her relatives, but no one has answered our calls or responded to our messages. Miry Nyabuto, Rose's grandmother who usually takes care of her when she's not in school, hasn't been responsive either.
Helpline Agent: I see. It sounds like Rose might be at risk. We need to ensure her immediate safety and wellbeing. Could you please provide me with the exact location where Rose was last seen?
Violet Wakesho: Unknown Landmark, Alale Ward, an unknown subcounty in West Pokot County.
Helpline Agent: Thank you for that information. I'm going to connect you with our social welfare team who will investigate this matter further and provide the necessary support to Rose. In the meantime, please keep trying to contact Rose's family and inform them about our concerns. If they don't respond, please ensure someone stays with Rose until help arrives.
Violet Wakesho: Thank you so much for your help. I appreciate it more than words can express.

category_definition: A condition characterized by an abnormal accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid in the brain.
narrative:
Violet Anyango: (sighs deeply) Hello, good day. I've been trying to find help for my granddaughter, Daisy Wakesho. She's only five years old and... (pauses) She's been having these severe headaches and her stomach swells up so much sometimes that she can hardly walk. The doctor here said it might be hydrocephalus, but we don't have the resources to treat her properly.
Agent: I'm truly sorry to hear about Daisy. Hydrocephalus is a serious condition that requires immediate attention. Have you considered reaching out to charities or NGOs that focus on child health and welfare? They might be able to assist you with the financial aspects of her treatment.
Violet Anyango: That's what I was hoping for, but I don't know where to start. There are so many organizations, and I'm not sure which ones are legitimate or if they even operate in our area.
Agent: Don't worry, I can help you with that. Let me find some resources for you. In the meantime, can you tell me more about Daisy's symptoms? How long have these been happening, and has she received any medical treatment so far?
Violet Anyango: (tears welling up) It started a few months ago. At first, I thought it was just growing pains, but they've only gotten worse. She's been to the local clinic several times, but they don't seem to know what's causing this. They just give her pain medication and send us home.
Agent: I see. It's important to get a proper diagnosis for Daisy as soon as possible. In the meantime, let me see if I can find some organizations that may be able to help you. While I do that, please ensure she doesn't miss any scheduled appointments at the local clinic and keep a record of all her symptoms and medications.
Violet Anyango: Thank you so much for your help. I appreciate it more than words can say.
Agent: You're very welcome. I'll do my best to assist you. In the meantime, if you have any other concerns or questions, don't hesitate to call back. We're here to help.

category_definition: Social interactions and relationships with individuals of similar age or status.
narrative:
Esther: Good day, I hope this line is working. I've been trying to find help for my daughter Miry Wawuda. She's only eleven and she's been through something terrible. It happened at her employer's place, Kelvin Mutie in Kalokol Ward, somewhere in Turkana County.
Helpline Agent: I'm sorry to hear that, Esther. Can you tell me more about what happened?
Esther: Well, it started a month ago when she was sent to the local shop by her employer to get some supplies. A group of boys from the neighborhood began making lewd comments at her. They followed her back and one of them grabbed her hand. She tried to pull away but he wouldn't let go, and another boy came and held her down while the first one... well, you can guess what happened next.
Helpline Agent: Oh my goodness, that sounds awful. Have you reported this to the police?
Esther: We have, but they said there was no evidence since it happened outside their jurisdiction. They also told us that Kelvin Mutie refused to cooperate with them. Since then, Miry has been acting differently. She's withdrawn and doesn't want to go out or play with her friends. I don't know what to do.
Helpline Agent: I understand how difficult this must be for you, Esther. It's important that we find a way to help Miry heal and feel safe again. We can provide counseling services and also work towards finding a new, safer employer for her. Would that be something you would consider?
Esther: Yes, I think that would be a good idea. I just want my daughter to be happy and protected. Can you tell me more about the counseling and how we can find another job for her?

category_definition: Infliction of physical injury upon a child through actions like hitting or shaking.
narrative:
Miriam had been in distress for days, her eyes swollen and bruised. She walked into school with a heavy limp, her usual cheerful demeanor replaced by an uncharacteristic silence. Petero, one of her teachers, noticed something was amiss.
"Miriam, are you feeling okay?" he asked, concern etched on his face. Miriam hesitated before responding, "I'm fine, Mr. Mutua."
"You don't seem fine, Miriam," Petero persisted. "Is there something bothering you at home? You can talk to me, you know."
Miriam sighed deeply, her shoulders slumping. "It's my brother, Jon. He... he beats me when he's drunk."
Petero's face hardened at the revelation. "Has this happened before?"
"Yes," Miriam whispered, her voice barely audible. "Many times. But I can't tell Mom or Dad. They won't believe me. Jon always finds a way to twist things."
Petero felt a surge of anger at the injustice and asked, "Have you ever sought help before?"
"I called a hotline once, but they couldn't do much. They only listened," Miriam replied, her voice filled with frustration.
Petero knew he had to take action. He said, "I can help you, Miriam. I will report this to the authorities and ensure you get the protection you need."
Miriam looked up at Petero, hope flickering in her eyes. "Thank you, Mr. Mutua. I don't know what I'd do without you."

category_definition: A condition resulting from a diet lacking in essential nutrients.
narrative:
Hello, you're speaking with John, a child protection counselor. I understand you have some concerns regarding Mike Mutie?
Caller: Yes, sir. He is my social work client. I am deeply worried about him. He is only eleven and seems to be suffering from malnutrition. I've tried reaching out to his employer but... she hasn't been responsive. I fear for his health and safety.
John: I see, and where is Mike currently located?
Caller: Last I heard, he was in Kwanza Ward, Unknown Subcounty, Trans Nzoia County. But his exact location is unknown as of now.
John: Thank you for sharing this information with me. It's crucial we act swiftly to ensure Mike receives the necessary care. First, let's verify Mike's condition and find his current whereabouts. Have you visited him personally lately?
Caller: No, unfortunately I haven't been able to see him in person due to various circumstances. But his health has deteriorated significantly as per my latest phone call with him. He's barely able to stand, and his speech is slurred.
John: I'm sorry to hear that. In this situation, it's important we take immediate action. Let me start by connecting you with our local social services in Trans Nzoia County. They can help us locate Mike and assess his condition.
Caller: That sounds like a good plan. Thank you so much for your assistance, John. I appreciate it.
John: Of course. We'll do everything possible to ensure Mike receives the help he needs. In the meantime, please keep me updated on any developments or changes in his condition. Remember, it's vital we find him as soon as possible.
Caller: I will, John. Thank you again for your help.
John: You're welcome. And remember, if you need to talk or have more questions, don't hesitate to call. Take care.

category_definition: Cultural, traditional, or religious acts that cause physical or psychological harm, such as FGM.
narrative:
Miry Akinyi: (teacher's voice) Hello, Child Helpline? I'm calling about a concerning issue regarding one of my students, Rose Gachoka. She's been absent for several days now, and when she did come back, she seemed... different. Distressed.
Helpline Agent: (soothing voice) I'm sorry to hear that, Ma'am. Can you tell me more about what you've noticed?
Miry Akinyi: (anxious tone) Well, she's been quieter than usual, and her eyes... They seem to hold a lot of fear. And there's this mark on her arm... It looks like a burn. I asked her about it, but she just shrugged it off and said she fell. But it didn't look like an accident.
Helpline Agent: (compassionate voice) I understand your concern, Ma'am. We need to ensure Rose's safety. Can you remember the last time you saw her? Or any details about where she might be now?
Miry Akinyi: (hesitant tone) I last saw her yesterday morning, at school. But... She didn't come for lunch, and when I asked her assistant teacher to check on her, he said Rose hadn't been seen since the afternoon recess. She usually goes home with a neighbor, Mike Wanyama, but... I don't think she was there yesterday.
Helpline Agent: (firm voice) Thank you for sharing this information, Ma'am. We will do our best to locate Rose and ensure her safety. Can I have your contact details in case we need more information from you?

category_definition: Concerns related to sexual development, reproductive systems, consent, and health education.
narrative:
Hello, you're speaking with Rachel at the Child Protection Helpline. How can I assist you today?
Caller: Hi there, I have a concern about my daughter Miriam. She's only ten years old and she lives in Nthawa Ward, but I don't know exactly where. Yesterday, she came home crying and wouldn't tell me what was wrong. When I finally managed to get her to speak, she said that Esther Akinyi, a classmate of hers, had touched her inappropriately at school.
Rachel: I'm so sorry to hear that, it's very important to take such concerns seriously. Can you tell me more about what happened? Did Miriam mention when or where this incident took place?
Caller: It seems it happened during recess time in the school compound. I don't know if Esther did it only once or if it has been happening repeatedly, but Miriam was very upset and didn't want to go back to school today. She said that Esther threatened her not to tell anyone about what she did.
Rachel: That sounds extremely alarming. I would recommend reporting this incident to the school authorities immediately and requesting them to conduct an investigation. It is crucial to ensure Miriam's safety and well-being, as well as that of other children in her class.
Caller: What if the school doesn't take action? What can we do then?
Rachel: If the school fails to address the issue, you have other options available. You could report the matter to the local police station or child protection services. It is important not to wait for further incidents to occur, as the longer this continues, the more distressing it will be for Miriam and potentially other children involved.
Caller: Thank you for your advice. I'll talk to my wife about our next steps and report the incident to the school tomorrow morning. Do you have any resources or contacts that could help us navigate this situation?
Rachel: Certainly, I can provide you with information on how to proceed and connect you with local organizations that specialize in child protection and gender-based violence. Additionally, I strongly encourage you to seek support for Miriam, as dealing with such trauma can be overwhelming for a young girl.
Caller: That sounds like a good plan. Thank you so much for your help. I feel a bit more confident now knowing that there are resources available for us.

category_definition: Excessive body fat that increases the risk of health problems.
narrative:
Hello, you're speaking with the East African Child Helpline. How may I assist you today?
Caller (Anxious): Hi, there's a child in need of help. She's a girl named Rose Atieno, she's 11 years old and lives somewhere in Sokoke Ward, Kilifi County. Her father, Ken Mwakio, is forcing her to eat unhealthy amounts of food. He's saying it's because she's too thin, but I think he's doing something wrong. She's struggling to walk and breathe normally now.
Agent (Empathetic): I understand your concern. It sounds like Rose may be suffering from obesity due to forced feeding. This is a serious matter that requires immediate attention. I appreciate your courage in reaching out for help.
Caller (Emotional): Yes, it's getting worse every day. She's been hiding in her room most of the time, and when she comes out, she moves slowly because of her weight. I can't stand by and watch this happen. What can we do?
Agent (Supportive): First, let's ensure Rose is safe. I recommend you reach out to local health authorities or social services for immediate intervention. They can assess Rose's condition, provide medical care if needed, and investigate the situation further.
Caller (Hopeful): Okay, I'll do that right away. Thank you so much for your help. I was so lost before I called.
Agent (Caring): You're very welcome. It takes a lot of courage to reach out and seek help. Please keep us updated on Rose's situation, and let us know if there are any other ways we can support you. Remember, you're not alone in this fight against child obesity.

category_definition: A diet that contains the proper proportions of carbohydrates, fats, proteins, vitamins, and minerals.
narrative:
Esther: Hello, I need urgent help. My grandson, Ken Kimeli, is in a critical situation. He's only twelve years old and he's been skipping meals for quite some time now. We live in Chepyuk Ward, Unknown Subcounty, Bungoma County, but I don't know the exact landmark. It's been going on for weeks now, and it's affecting his health and well-being.
Operator: I see, Esther. I'm really sorry to hear about Ken. Can you tell me more about what's happening? How did this start, and what have you tried so far to address the issue?
Esther: It started when his peer, Ken Muema, began making fun of him for being thin. They are classmates at school, and it's been really tough on Ken. He tried to talk to his teacher about it, but nothing has changed. He skips meals now because he doesn't want to eat in front of them, fearing their ridicule.
Operator: That sounds incredibly difficult for him. Skipping meals can have severe consequences for a growing boy like Ken. Have you spoken with anyone else about this situation, such as a school counselor or a doctor?
Esther: I've talked to the teacher, but they said there's nothing they can do unless there's proof of bullying. We visited a doctor who advised us to ensure Ken eats a balanced diet and gets regular exercise. But with the constant teasing at school, it's hard for him to eat properly or focus on anything else.
Operator: I understand your concerns, Esther. It's essential that Ken receives the necessary support to maintain a healthy lifestyle. One option could be to seek help from a nutritionist who specializes in child development and can provide guidance on meal planning and portion control. Additionally, reporting the bullying to the school administration is crucial, as they have a responsibility to ensure a safe learning environment for all students.
Esther: That sounds like a good plan. Thank you for your advice. Do you know of any nutritionists or organizations that can help us?
Operator: I can certainly provide some resources and referrals for you. The Kenyan Nutrition Association (KNA) is a reputable organization that offers nutritional services and support for children. Additionally, the Ministry of Health's Child Welfare Department may be able to offer further assistance.
Esther: Thank you so much for your help. I will reach out to those organizations immediately.

category_definition: Involving a child in sexual activity that they cannot comprehend or consent to.
narrative:
Rose Waboshe (distressed): Hello, I need someone to talk to. My grandson, Ken Mwangi, he's been through something terrible. He's only sixteen and he... he's been abused.
Helpline Agent (comforting tone): I'm so sorry to hear that, Rose. Can you tell me more about what happened? Where is Ken now?
Rose Waboshe (worried tone): It happened in Kisumu North Ward, Unknown Subcounty, Kisumu County. We don't know the exact location. He ran away from home last night after he called me, crying and mumbling about a stranger named Jon Wanyama. I tried to find him but... I couldn't.
Helpline Agent (sympathetic tone): That sounds very frightening. Have you reported this incident to the local authorities?
Rose Waboshe (guilty tone): No, I haven't. I was too afraid of what people might say or think. But... I can't just sit here and do nothing. I need help.
Helpline Agent (firm tone): It's important that you report this to the authorities, Rose. They can provide the necessary assistance and protection for Ken. While we wait for them to arrive, is there someone safe where Ken can stay until then?
Rose Waboshe (tearful tone): My daughter lives in a different town, but she's willing to take him in. I just... I don't know what to do next.
Helpline Agent (reassuring tone): That sounds like a good plan. In the meantime, try to find Ken and bring him to safety. If you need any further assistance or guidance, please don't hesitate to call us back. We're here for you.
Rose Waboshe (grateful tone): Thank you so much. You've been a great help. I... I'll do my best to find Ken and get him to safety.

category_definition: The presence of two or more disabling conditions in an individual.
narrative:
Mary (distressed): Good day, I am Mary. My son, James Muema, is in grave danger and I don't know what to do. He has multiple disabilities, and my other child, Jon Sali, is taking advantage of his condition. They are currently living in a place somewhere in Nzaui/Kilili/Kalamba Ward, but I can't be certain about the exact location. I believe they might be in Makueni County.
Operator (empathetic): I'm truly sorry to hear that, Mary. Can you please tell me more about what's been happening with James and Jon?
Mary (tearful): Ever since James was diagnosed with multiple disabilities, things have been difficult for us. But lately, things have gotten worse. Jon has started to bully James and he's been neglecting his basic needs. I've tried talking to him, but it only makes things worse. He just doesn't care.
Operator (sympathetic): This sounds like a very distressing situation for you and your son. Have there been any specific incidents that you can recall?
Mary (anxious): Yes, yesterday Jon locked James in a room without food or water for the entire day. I only found out because James managed to call me on my phone. I rushed home immediately, but when I got there, I couldn't do anything. Jon had already let him out and was pretending like nothing happened.
Operator (compassionate): This is a serious matter, Mary. You need to get help for both of your sons as soon as possible. Have you considered reaching out to any local organizations that specialize in child protection or disability services?
Mary (hesitant): I have thought about it, but I don't know who to trust. We live in a small community and word travels fast. I'm afraid of the stigma associated with having a son with disabilities and the potential backlash we might face.
Operator (understanding): I understand your concerns, Mary. However, it's crucial that you seek help for James and ensure his safety. There are organizations that prioritize confidentiality and can provide support without revealing your identity. Can I connect you with one such organization today?
Mary (relieved): Yes, please do. I just want to make sure my son is safe and receives the care he needs.

narrative:
Miriam's voice trembled as she spoke, "Hello, I... I need help. I don't know who to turn to."

I could sense her fear and desperation through the phone line. "You've reached the East African Child Helpline. I'm here to listen. Can you tell me what's happened?"

She took a deep breath before continuing, "It's my father... he's been hurting me... physically and emotionally." She paused for a moment, gathering her strength. "I don't know where else to go."

I offered her some reassurance, "It's okay, Miriam. You've taken the first step by reaching out. I want you to know that you're not alone."

She started to cry, and I could hear the pain in her voice. "This has been going on for so long... and I'm scared."

I tried to comfort her, "I understand how scary this must be, but there are people who can help you. Can you tell me more about where you are right now?"

She gave me a location, which I noted down carefully. I then asked if she was safe at the moment and if there was anyone else in the house who could harm her.

Miriam confirmed that she was currently hiding and that no one else was home. I asked her if she had a phone with her that her father didn't know about. She said yes, but it was running low on battery.

I quickly explained some options to her. "We can arrange for someone from the local Child Welfare Services to come and pick you up. But we need to make sure you're safe first."

Miriam agreed, and I asked her to stay on the line until help arrived. I reassured her that they would be there soon and that she would be safe.
text:
Miriam's voice trembled as she spoke, "Hello, I... I need help. I don't know who to turn to."

I could sense her fear and desperation through the phone line. "You've reached the East African Child Helpline. I'm here to listen. Can you tell me what's happened?"

She took a deep breath before continuing, "It's my father... he's been hurting me... physically and emotionally." She paused for a moment, gathering her strength. "I don't know where else to go."

I offered her some reassurance, "It's okay, Miriam. You've taken the first step by reaching out. I want you to know that you're not alone."

She started to cry, and I could hear the pain in her voice. "This has been going on for so long... and I'm scared."

I tried to comfort her, "I understand how scary this must be, but there are people who can help you. Can you tell me more about where you are right now?"

She gave me a location, which I noted down carefully. I then asked if she was safe at the moment and if there was anyone else in the house who could harm her.

Miriam confirmed that she was currently hiding and that no one else was home. I asked her if she had a phone with her that her father didn't know about. She said yes, but it was running low on battery.

I quickly explained some options to her. "We can arrange for someone from the local Child Welfare Services to come and pick you up. But we need to make sure you're safe first."

Miriam agreed, and I asked her to stay on the line until help arrived. I reassured her that they would be there soon and that she would be safe.

category_definition: Problems such as performance, discipline, bullying, or lack of resources at school.
narrative:
Daisy Wakio: Hello there, I hope you're doing well. It's been a while since we spoke about Miriam, my granddaughter. She's still in that awful situation...
Helpline Agent: Oh dear, I am sorry to hear that Daisy. How has she been coping with school? Has there been any improvement?
Daisy Wakio: No, it's getting worse by the day. The step-parent, James Aboge, he's still making her life unbearable. He's not letting her attend school regularly and when she does, he humiliates her in front of her classmates.
Helpline Agent: I see, that sounds very concerning. Has Miriam discussed this with anyone at school? A teacher or counselor maybe?
Daisy Wakio: She tried to tell the teacher once but nothing happened. They just dismissed it as a 'family matter'. And as for a counselor, there isn't one at her school. We live in a remote area, you know.
Helpline Agent: I understand your predicament. Daisy, have you considered reaching out to local authorities or child welfare services? They may be able to intervene and ensure Miriam's rights are protected.
Daisy Wakio: We've tried, but it's complicated. The authorities don't seem interested in our case and we fear for Miriam's safety if we take more drastic steps.
Helpline Agent: I appreciate your concerns. Let me see what I can do to help. In the meantime, I urge you to keep documenting any incidents that occur. This could be valuable evidence if we decide to report the matter to the authorities again.
Daisy Wakio: Thank you for your advice and support. It means a lot to us.

category_definition: A situation where a child lacks a responsible adult to provide basic care and support.
narrative:
Esther Wakesho (voice shaking): Good day, I need urgent assistance. My son Petero Wanyama, he's sixteen years old and he's been with his father in Kilungu Ward, Unknown Subcounty, Makueni County for the past few weeks. But now, no one seems to know where he is. His father, Ken Sali, well, he's been violent towards us and Petero before. I fear something terrible has happened to him.
Agent (calm but empathetic): I'm so sorry to hear about your concerns, Ms. Wakesho. We understand how distressing this situation must be for you. Can you tell me more about the last time you spoke with Petero or received any information about his whereabouts?
Esther Wakesho (voice trembling): The last I heard was a week ago when he called saying he was staying at a relative's place temporarily. But since then, no one has picked up his calls and there's been no sign of him at home or at the relative's.
Agent (sympathetic): I see. It sounds like you're in a very difficult situation. Firstly, let me assure you that we are here to help. We can report this case as missing and also reach out to local authorities to initiate a search for Petero. Additionally, we can provide counseling support for you during this stressful time.
Esther Wakesho (grateful): Thank you so much. I really appreciate your help. What should I do next?
Agent (helpful): We'll need some more information from you, such as the name and contact details of Petero's relative, and any other places where he might have gone. Once we have that, we can take further steps to locate him and ensure his safety. In the meantime, please try not to worry too much. Our team will do everything we can to help you find your son.
Esther Wakesho (determined): I understand. I'll gather the information as soon as possible and contact you back. Thank you again for your assistance.
Agent (supportive): You're welcome, Ms. Wakesho. We're here to help, so please don't hesitate to reach out if you need anything else. Take care.

narrative:
Hello, welcome to East African Child Helpline. How may I assist you today?
Caller: Hello, I'm calling because there's a situation involving a young girl named Eunice Atieno. She lives somewhere in an unknown area, and I've noticed that she hasn't been receiving her school maintenance fees regularly. Her education is at risk due to this.
Agent: I see, that's concerning. Could you provide more details about Eunice's location or any other information that might help us trace her? Also, have you spoken to her parents or guardians about this issue?
Caller: Well, I don't know exactly where she lives, but it's somewhere in a rural area. And as for her parents, I believe they are struggling financially, which is why the maintenance fees aren't being paid. They might need help with that.
Agent: Understood. We can certainly look into providing assistance for Eunice's maintenance fees if necessary. However, it would be beneficial to reach out to her parents or guardians first and understand the full extent of their financial situation. In addition, we could explore other resources that might offer support in this case.
Caller: That sounds like a good idea. I don't want to burden them with more debt if there are other options available. What should I do next?
Agent: We can work together to find the best solution for Eunice. First, I will gather some information about resources in her area that may be able to help with school fees or provide financial assistance. Meanwhile, you could reach out to her parents or guardians and explain the situation, letting them know about our services and seeing if they would like to discuss their options.
Caller: Alright, I'll do that. Thank you so much for your help. This means a lot to me.
Agent: You're welcome. If you need any further assistance or have questions along the way, feel free to reach out to us again. We're here to help.

category_definition: Excessive body fat that increases the risk of health problems.
narrative:
Daisy Waboshe: (deep sigh) Hello there... I don't know what to do. My son Daniel... he's been gaining weight so rapidly and it's worrying me. I can't seem to find a solution, no matter how hard I try.
Crisis Support Agent: I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through this. Let's see if we can work something out together. Can you tell me more about Daniel's condition and what steps have you taken so far?
Daisy Waboshe: (tearful) Oh... it all started a year ago, after his father passed away. Ever since then, I've noticed he's been eating more than usual, and not just at meal times. He snacks in between meals too, and sometimes even late at night. I've tried talking to him but he just dismisses my concerns as if they don't matter.
Crisis Support Agent: I see... It sounds like a difficult situation. Grief can often manifest in unusual ways, including changes in eating habits. Have you considered speaking with a professional who specializes in childhood obesity and can provide guidance on appropriate interventions?
Daisy Waboshe: (hesitant) I've thought about it... but the cost is prohibitive. I don't know if we can afford it. Plus, we live out in Mosiro Ward, Unknown Subcounty, Kajiado County... finding a specialist is no easy task.
Crisis Support Agent: I understand your concerns. In such situations, it might be helpful to connect with local health centers or community organizations that offer resources and support for children's health issues like obesity. They may have more affordable options available. Additionally, you could reach out to schools and inquire if they have any partnerships or connections with specialists or resources that could help.
Daisy Waboshe: (hopeful) That sounds promising... I'll definitely give it a try. Thank you so much for your help. I feel a little more hopeful now.

category_definition: A formal or informal union involving a child below the age of 18.
narrative:
Esther Chao: Hello, I'm calling from a distress. I have a problem that I need help with. My daughter Violet Akinyi, she is only thirteen years old and... and Mike Kimeli, my son, he wants to marry her. I don't know what to do, this is not right.
Helpline Agent: I'm so sorry to hear about your situation, Ms. Chao. Child marriage is a serious issue and it's important that we take steps to protect Violet. Can you tell me more about what has happened? When did this start? Where are they now?
Esther Chao: This has been going on for some time now. Mike... he keeps telling me that it's his right since she is from our family. But I know it's not right. They are in Unknown Landmark, Masige East Ward, Unknown Subcounty, Kisii County.
Helpline Agent: I understand your concern, Ms. Chao. Child marriage is illegal and a violation of Violet's rights. I will do my best to help you. Firstly, we need to ensure Violet's immediate safety. Can you please tell me if there are any adults who can support her at the moment?
Esther Chao: (pausing) Yes, thankfully there is an auntie who lives nearby and she has agreed to take care of Violet. But I fear for her safety if they stay there. Mike is quite aggressive.
Helpline Agent: I see, it's crucial that we take action immediately. I will contact the local authorities and inform them about the situation. In the meantime, please ensure Violet stays with this auntie but in a safe location. If possible, try to keep her away from Mike for now.
Esther Chao: (relieved) Thank you so much. This has been weighing on me heavily, and I didn't know who to turn to.
Helpline Agent: You are very welcome, Ms. Chao. It's important that you take care of yourself as well during this time. Once the authorities have taken action, they will contact you with further updates. If you need any more help or support, please don't hesitate to call us back.

category_definition: Problems such as performance, discipline, bullying, or lack of resources at school.
narrative:
James Kimeli: Good day, ma'am. I hope this call finds you well. There's a matter concerning one of our students that I need your assistance with. The child's name is Miriam Atieno. She's only four years old and has been attending our school in Mukothima Ward, but unfortunately, her situation at home has become quite distressing.
Helpline Agent: I see. Could you please tell me more about what's happening?
James Kimeli: Yes, of course. Miriam has been subjected to verbal and emotional abuse by a classmate named Ken Mutie. It started with name-calling, but it has escalated to physical abuse lately. I found bruises on her body yesterday, and when I asked her about it, she cried and wouldn't tell me what happened.
Helpline Agent: I'm really sorry to hear that, Mr. Kimeli. This is a serious matter and needs immediate attention. Have you reported this incident to the school authorities or local police yet?
James Kimeli: Not yet, ma'am. I wanted to get some advice on how best to approach this situation before taking any action. I'm worried that if I confront Ken, it might escalate further and put Miriam at even greater risk.
Helpline Agent: You are right to be concerned about the child's safety. However, it is crucial that you take steps to ensure her protection. I recommend reporting this incident to both the school authorities and local police as soon as possible. The school should have a policy for handling cases of bullying and violence, and the police can provide additional support and legal action if necessary.
James Kimeli: Thank you for your advice, ma'am. I will report the incident today. Is there anything else I should do or consider?
Helpline Agent: Yes, it would be beneficial to keep a record of any further incidents or evidence that may arise. If possible, try to speak with Miriam privately and reassure her that she is safe and that you are here to help. Encourage her to tell you if anything happens again so that you can take immediate action.
James Kimeli: I will do that, ma'am. Thank you for your assistance. I feel a bit more confident now about dealing with this situation.
Helpline Agent: You're welcome, Mr. Kimeli. If you need further support or have any questions, please don't hesitate to call us again. We are here to help. Take care.

category_definition: Practices surrounding safe and nutritious food preparation and feeding habits.
narrative:
Miriam Akinyi: Hello, I need to speak with someone about my daughter, Angy Wairimu. She's been going through a difficult time lately, and it's affecting her eating habits.
Helpline Agent: I'm really sorry to hear that. Can you tell me more about what's been happening?
Miriam Akinyi: It all started when James Mutie, our neighbor, began making lewd comments towards Angy. She's only twelve years old and it's been traumatizing for her.
Helpline Agent: I understand your concern, Ma'am. Has she mentioned anything about not having enough food to eat?
Miriam Akinyi: Yes, she has. She's barely eating these days. And when she does, it's just a small portion. I've tried talking to her, but she doesn't want to discuss it.
Helpline Agent: It's important that we get her the help she needs. Can you tell me where you live so we can arrange for someone to visit and assess the situation?
Miriam Akinyi: We're in an Unknown Landmark, Kabula Ward, Unknown Subcounty, Bungoma County. I hope that helps.
Helpline Agent: Thank you for that information. Our team will reach out to you soon to discuss further steps. In the meantime, please encourage Angy to eat regularly and seek medical help if she shows any signs of illness due to malnutrition.
Miriam Akinyi: Thank you for your help. I appreciate it more than words can express.
Helpline Agent: You're very welcome, Ma'am. Remember, we're here to help. Take care and stay strong.

category_definition: Information about how to access helpline services and support.
narrative:
Violet Nyaboke: Hello, I've stumbled upon something concerning and I need your help. A child named Mary Waboshe, aged 11, is in distress. She's been living with her relative Daisy Atieno in Kangundo East Ward, but recently, I fear things have taken a turn for the worse.
Operator: I'm sorry to hear that, Violet. Can you tell me more about what's been happening?
Violet Nyaboke: She's been acting differently. She's become withdrawn, and there are signs of physical injuries on her body. I've noticed she's been crying a lot and seems scared to speak when Daisy is around. I thought it best to reach out for help.
Operator: Thank you for bringing this to our attention, Violet. I appreciate your concern for Mary's wellbeing. The helpline can provide support and resources to help keep children safe from harm.
Violet Nyaboke: That's a relief to hear. Can you tell me what steps should be taken next?
Operator: Absolutely, Violet. We will need to gather more information about Mary's situation and the specific location where she is living. This will help us to offer appropriate assistance and ensure her safety.
Violet Nyaboke: I understand. The address is Unknown Landmark, Kangundo East Ward, Unknown Subcounty, Machakos County. I'm not completely sure about the exact sub-location, but I believe it's near a small market.
Operator: Thank you for that information, Violet. We will now dispatch a social worker to assess Mary's situation and provide any necessary support. In the meantime, it's important that you do not confront Daisy Atieno about this matter as it could potentially put Mary in more danger.
Violet Nyaboke: I understand, operator. Thank you for your help and guidance during this difficult time.
Operator: You're welcome, Violet. Please rest assured that we will do everything possible to ensure Mary's safety. If you have any further questions or concerns, feel free to reach out to us at any time.

category_definition: The illegal movement or exploitation of children, often for labor, sexual exploitation, or criminal activity.
narrative:
Miriam Wakio: Good day, I have a situation that's been troubling me for quite some time now. My daughter, Angy Nyaboke, who is only seven years old, has been missing for over a week now. We last saw her at our home in Kangundo North Ward, but she's nowhere to be found. I've reported this to the local police, but they haven't been able to find any leads. I'm at my wit's end, and I don't know what else to do.
Helpline Agent: I see, I'm truly sorry to hear about your situation, Miriam Wakio. Child trafficking cases are unfortunately quite common in our region. There are several steps you can take to ensure the safety of your daughter. Firstly, it would be beneficial to spread the word within your community and local authorities about your missing child. The more eyes looking out for her, the higher the chances of finding her.
Miriam Wakio: Yes, we've been doing that, but so far, there's been no luck. I fear she may have been taken somewhere far away.
Helpline Agent: It's understandable to worry. In such cases, it's crucial to collaborate with other organizations and institutions specialized in child protection. They can provide assistance in tracing missing children and offer guidance on the best strategies for finding your daughter. I can help connect you with some of these organizations if you wish.
Miriam Wakio: That would be amazing. I just want my daughter back, no matter what it takes.
Helpline Agent: Of course. In addition to involving child protection organizations, it's also important to investigate any potential leads, even the slightest ones. For example, have you checked with anyone who may have had access to your home or interacted with your daughter recently?
Miriam Wakio: I have, but no one seems to know anything about her whereabouts. It's as if she vanished into thin air.
Helpline Agent: While it's difficult, it's essential not to give up hope. Child trafficking cases can be complex and require patience and perseverance. I will connect you with the child protection organizations, and they can guide you on what steps to take next. In the meantime, if anything new comes up or if you have any questions, don't hesitate to reach out again. We are here to help.

category_definition: Partial or total inability to hear, affecting communication and learning.
narrative:
Eunice: Good day, I hope you are well. I'm calling about my little girl, Rose. She's three years old and has been deaf since birth. We live in an isolated area in Kamenu Ward, and it's becoming increasingly difficult to manage. The local school doesn't cater to children with special needs, so she can't go there. I've tried teaching her myself, but it's been challenging. I feel overwhelmed and don't know where to turn for help.
Agent: I understand your concerns, Eunice. It's important that Rose receives the appropriate education and care she needs. I can provide you with some resources that might help. Have you considered signing her up for a specialized school or program? There are organizations in Kiambu County that cater to children with hearing impairments.
Eunice: Yes, I have looked into it, but the cost is prohibitive. We barely make ends meet as it is.
Agent: I understand that financial constraints can be a significant hurdle. Let me see if there are any scholarships or grants available for such institutions. Additionally, I can connect you with local support groups where parents of hearing-impaired children share their experiences and offer advice.
Eunice: That sounds wonderful. I would really appreciate that. It would be a relief to talk to someone who understands our situation.
Agent: Of course, Eunice. I'll do my best to find suitable resources for you and your daughter. In the meantime, if you have any questions or concerns, don't hesitate to reach out. Remember, it's important not to lose hope. Many children with hearing impairments lead fulfilling lives with the right support.

category_definition: Any sexual act or attempt to obtain a sexual act through coercion or without consent.
narrative:
Jon's voice trembled as he spoke into the phone. "I don't know what to do..." He paused, taking a deep breath before continuing, his words coming out in a rush. "My employer... John Aboge... he touched me... I didn't want him to but he did." He sobbed quietly, tears streaming down his face.
Mary, the helpline agent, remained calm and empathetic. "I'm so sorry that you're going through this, Jon. It's not your fault. You have done nothing wrong." She paused, allowing him to gather himself.
"It happened at work... in Juja Ward, Subcounty, Kiambu County. I don't know what to do. He threatened me if I told anyone." Jon's voice was small and scared.
Mary reassured him. "I understand that this is difficult, but it's important that you tell someone. You are not alone in this." She paused, considering her next words carefully. "Have you told anyone else about what happened?"
Jon shook his head. "No... I didn't want to get him into trouble... or lose my job..."
Mary's voice was firm but gentle. "It's not about getting John Aboge into trouble, Jon. It's about ensuring that you are safe and protected from harm." She paused again, giving Jon time to process what she had said.
"But... what can I do?" Jon asked, his voice filled with despair.
Mary began to list options for Jon. "Firstly, I would recommend reporting the incident to the police. They can investigate and take action against John Aboge." She paused, considering her next words. "Additionally, you may want to consider speaking to a counselor who specializes in sexual violence. They can provide support and help you cope with what has happened."
